Description: N.C. COASTAL LAND TRUST PROPOSES TO ACQUIRE IN FEE TITLE A 17.73-ACRE PROPERTY ALONG THE CHOWAN RIVER NEAR THE TOWN OF COLERAIN IN BERTIE COUNTY.  20,000 DOLLARS REQUESTED FOR CONVEYANCE WORK (SURVEY, TITLE ETC.  NONE OF THIS FUNDING WILL GO TOWARD PURCHASE PRICE) THE DISTINCTIVE FEATURE OF THE PROPERTY IS A 8590-FOOT BLUFF ALONG THE RIVER. THE PROPERTY LIES WITHIN A LANDSCAPE OF OTHER CONSERVATION LANDS ALONG THE CHOWAN RIVER FROM THE VIRGINIA NORTH CAROLINA STATE LINE TO THE ALBEMARLE SOUND. FROM THE NORTH, N.C. WILDLIFE RESOURCES COMMISSION OWNS AND MANAGES OVER 30,000 ACRES OF LAND, THE CHOWAN SWAMP GAME LAND, ALONG THE RIVER. NEAR THE ALBEMARLE SOUND, N.C. COASTAL LAND TRUST PURCHASED OVER 1,300-ACRES OF LAND ALONG THE CHOWAN RIVER AT THE CONFLUENCE OF SALMON CREEK AND THE ALBEMARLE SOUND. THE PROPERTY WAS TRANSFERRED TO THE STATE TO BE MANAGED BY N.C. DIVISION OF PARKS AND RECREATION AS THE NEW SALMON CREEK STATE NATURAL AREA. IN ADDITION, THE POINT COMFORT TRACT LIES JUST 2 MILES SOUTH OF OVER 1,180 ACRES OF LAND ALONG THE CHOWAN RIVER THAT WAS RECENTLY PURCHASED, CONSERVED, AND TRANSFERRED BY N.C. COASTAL LAND TRUST TO THE STATE TO BECOME PART OF THE CHOWAN SWAMP GAME LANDS. THE CHOWAN POINT COMFORT TRACT HAS BEEN CALLED THE  CROWN JEWEL OF THE ALBEMARLE  AND HAS GEOLOGIC, ECOLOGICAL, SCENIC AND EDUCATIONAL VALUES. IF SUCCESSFUL IN PURCHASING THE PROPERTY, THE COASTAL LAND TRUST WILL MANAGE IT AS A NATURE PRESERVE AND WILL HOST GROUP EDUCATIONAL TOURS OF THE PROPERTY.

CENTRALLY LOCATED IN NORTHERN MICHIGAN WITHIN THE NORTH AMERICAN LAURENTIAN GREAT LAKES BASIN, THE OBTAWAING BIOSPHERE REGION (OBR) LIES AT THE CONVERGENCE OF TWO PENINSULAS, THREE GREAT LAKES, AND NUMEROUS CULTURES. IN 2021, UNESCO RECOGNIZED THE OBR IN ITS MAN AND THE BIOSPHERE PROGRAMME AS A REGION OF GLOBAL ECOLOGICAL AND CULTURAL SIGNIFICANCE. THE EXISTING PARTNERSHIP NETWORK HAS IDENTIFIED THE NEED FOR COORDINATED REGIONAL PLANNING FOR COASTAL SYSTEMS. THROUGH THIS REGIONAL STAKEHOLDER AND TRIBAL LEADERSHIP WILL BE ENGAGED IN CONSERVATION AND CLIMATE RESILIENCE AND ADAPTATION PLANNING. GREAT LAKES REGIONAL PLANS, DECISION-MAKING TOOLS, AND DATA WILL BE COMPILED, SYNTHESIZED AND INTEGRATED INTO COORDINATED SUB-REGIONAL TO LOCAL PLANS AND ON-THE-GROUND EFFORTS RESULTING IN A PRIORITIZED COASTAL PROJECT LIST FOR ADDITIONAL FUNDING EXPLORATION.

THERE IS A SEVERE AND GROWING POPULATION OF PURPLE STAR THISTLE (CENTAUREA CALCITRAPA L.), IN FIELDS ALONGSIDE YTIAS CREEK AND WIDELY SPREAD POPULATION OF ARTICHOKE THISTLE (CYNARA CARDUNCULUS), INCLUDING DENSE AREAS OF MONOCULTURE, ON THE HILLSIDES WITHIN THE PROPERTY BOUNDARIES. BOTH THESE PLANT SPECIES ARE CREATING EXPANDING MONOCULTURES CREATING A DECLINE IN OVERALL NATIVE VEGETATIVE BIODIVERSITY WHICH IS HABITAT OF MANY ANIMAL SPECIES INCLUDING THE WESTERN MEADOW LARK. THE PURPLE STAR THISTLE IS A MORE RECENT OCCURRENCE AND COVERS A SMALLER AREA OF THE PROPERTY. IT HAS PROPAGATED QUICKLY AND SHOULD BE CONTAINED BEFORE IT IS UNCONTROLLABLE. THIS PLANT HAS ALLELOPATHIC EFFECTS WHICH ALSO CAUSE IMPACT ON NATIVE VEGETATION GROWTH AND BIODIVERSITY AS WELL AS THE DENSITY OF ITS GROWTH COVERAGE. BEFORE SUSTAINED MANAGEMENT OF THIS PROBLEM CAN OCCUR, LARGE SCALE AND INTENSIVE TREATMENT MUST REDUCE THE CURRENT POPULATION. THE PLAN IS TO SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCE THE PRESENT POPULATION OF PURPLE STAR THISTLE TO A MORE MANAGEABLE SIZE AND ESTABLISH A FOOTHOLD FOR LONG TERM SUSTAINED MANAGEMENT. CHANNEL ISLANDS RESTORATION (CIR) STAFF ARE HIGHLY TRAINED IN RESTORATION WORK IN REMOTE AREAS, NATIVE SPECIES IN LOCAL ENVIRONMENTS AND HERBICIDE TREATMENTS, SPECIALIZING IN SURGICAL APPLICATIONS AROUND SENSITIVE AND ENDANGERED SPECIES. THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCE THE CURRENT POPULATIONS OF PURPLE STAR THISTLE AND OTHER INVASIVE SPECIES WITH MINIMAL DAMAGE TO ANY NATIVE VEGETATION, CREATING AN ENVIRONMENT WHERE THE NATIVE PLANTS CAN QUICKLY CAPITALIZE ON THE AVAILABLE RESOURCES AND REVEGETATE THE VOIDS LEFT WHEN THE THISTLES ARE GONE.

THE CONSERVATION FUND OWNS AND MANAGES 3,792 ACRES OF WETLANDS AND COASTAL PRAIRIE THAT IT WILL CONVEY IT TO THE USFWS IN SUMMER OF 2025 TO BECOME PART OF MCFADDIN NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE. BECAUSE OUR LAND WILL SOON BE OWNED BY USFWS, WE WORK IN CONJUNCTION WITH USFWS STAFF AT MCFADDIN NWR USING A HOLISTIC APPROACH TO RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT OF THE PROPERTY.TCF PROPOSES TO RESTORE HYDROLOGIC FUNCTION TO GATOR LAKE ON THE PROPERTY, A RAINWATER-FED LAKE OF APPROXIMATELY 100 ACRES THAT PROVIDES EXCELLENT WATERFOWL AND WATERBIRD HABITAT. THE CURRENT WATER CONTROL STRUCTURES HAVE FALLEN INTO DISREPAIR, PREVENTING MANAGERS FROM MOVING WATER ACROSS THE PROPERTY DURING FLOOD EVENTS AND THREATENING A LOSS OF HABITAT DUE TO BACKED UP STANDING WATER ON THE PRAIRIE. CURRENTLY DURING FLOOD EVENTS, WATER BUILDS UP BEHIND THE BULKHEADS, FLOODING UP TO 900 ACRES IN THE NORTHERN PART OF SABINE RANCH AND INUNDATING THE PRAIRIE SPECIES IN THIS AREA, AS ESTIMATED BY MCFADDIN NWR STAFF. FUNDS WILL BE USED TO REMOVE THE CURRENT BULKHEADS AND GATES AND INSTALL FOUR NEW BULKHEADS AND WATER CONTROL GATES.

THE COASTAL PROGRAM, LAGUNA ATASCOSA NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (LANWR), AND THE FRIENDS OF LAGUNA ATASCOSA NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (FLANWR) ARE INTERESTED IN HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS AND PROVIDING SUPPORT FOR LAND ACQUISITION. THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE TO WORK AT LANWR AND LAND OWNED BY FLANWR TO CONSERVE AND ENHANCE 500 ACRES OF HABITAT FOR APLOMADO FALCONS, OCELOTS, AND WATERFOWL. A SECONDARY OBJECTIVE WILL BE TO HELP FACILITATE LAND ACQUISITION BY FLANWR BY PROVIDING DUE DILIGENCE FUNDS FOR FLANWR FOR THE PURPOSE OF HABITAT CONSERVATION, FOCUSING ON THE COASTAL CORRIDOR. WORK WILL INCLUDE HABITAT RESTORATION OF THORNSCRUB, COASTAL PRAIRIE, AND WETLAND HABITATS ON LANWR. ADDITIONALLY, FUNDING WILL ALSO BE USED FOR DUE DILIGENCE COSTS (SURVEYS, APPRAISALS, AND LAWYER FEES) FOR LAND ACQUISITION PROJECTS UNDERTAKEN BY FLANWR. THESE LANDS WILL BE TRANSFERRED TO THE USFWS AND BECOME PART OF LANWR.

PROJECT GOAL: THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO PREVENT PERMANENT LOSS OF NATIVE HABITATS AND POPULATIONS OF RARE SPECIES (SALT MARSH BIRDS-BEAK, BELDINGS SAVANNAH SPARROW, CALIFORNIA LEAST TERN, WESTERN SNOWY PLOVER, AND NUTTALLS ACMISPON) ON THE REFUGE. THE PROJECT WILL LOCATE AND CONTROL NONNATIVE LIMONIUM WITHIN THE REFUGE AND ON CONSERVED LANDS ADJACENT TO THE REFUGE. THE PROJECT AREA IS 183 ACRES AND INCLUDES SUSCEPTIBLE HABITAT IN AND ADJACENT TO THE REFUGES SWEETWATER MARSH UNIT, WHICH INCLUDES SWEETWATER MARSH, CONNECTOR MARSH, D STREET FILL, MARISMA DE NACION, PARADISE MARSH, AND THE USS MIDWAY MUSEUM MITIGATION PROPERTY, AND IN AND ADJACENT TO THE SOUTH SAN DIEGO BAY UNIT, WHICH INCLUDES THE OTAY RIVER, WESTERN SALT PONDS, CHULA VISTA WILDLIFE RESERVE AND EMORY COVE. SURVEYS WILL DOCUMENT THE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF NONNATIVE LIMONIUM, IDENTIFY AND TARGET TREATMENT LOCATIONS TO CONTROL OCCURRENCES, AND TRACK SUCCESS TOWARDS MEETING THE GOAL OF A 99  REDUCTION IN NONNATIVE LIMONIUM BY JUNE 2025. DETAILED OBJECTIVES TO MEET THIS GOAL ARE LISTED BELOW. OBJECTIVE 1: THE DISTRIBUTION OF NONNATIVE LIMONIUM WILL BE MAPPED THROUGHOUT THE PROJECT AREA. IN 2022, THE PROJECT CONDUCTED STANDARDIZED SURVEYS AND MAPPING WITHIN SUSCEPTIBLE HABITAT THROUGHOUT SAN DIEGO BAY IN AREAS THAT HAD NOT BEEN PREVIOUSLY SURVEYED. THE SURVEY DATA WAS ENTERED INTO A PROJECT-SPECIFIC DATA COLLECTION APPLICATION CREATED IN ARCGIS FIELD MAPS. IN 2023, THE PROJECT WILL SURVEY AND MAP IN THE AREAS WITHIN THE PROJECT AREA THAT WERE NOT INCLUDED IN THE 2022 SURVEY TO COMPLETE A COMPREHENSIVE MAP USING THE STANDARDIZED SURVEY METHODOLOGY. SURVEYS SHOULD BE CONDUCTED IN JUNE AND JULY WHEN THE SPECIES IS IN FLOWER AND EASIEST TO DETECT. IN 2025, THE PROJECT WILL REPEAT THE COMPREHENSIVE SURVEY IN ALL SUSCEPTIBLE HABITAT WITHIN THE PROJECT AREA. OBJECTIVE 2: APPROXIMATELY 100  OF MAPPED NONNATIVE LIMONIUM ON REFUGE LANDS AND ADJACENT PROPERTIES WILL BE REMOVED WITH EITHER SOLARIZATION TARPING OR HAND REMOVAL BY JUNE 2025. THE PROJECT WILL ANNUALLY SURVEY AND MAP CONTROL TREATMENT LOCATIONS TO DOCUMENT TREATMENT SUCCESS AND INFORM SUBSEQUENT TREATMENTS. OBJECTIVE 3: A 99  REDUCTION IN THE DISTRIBUTION OF NONNATIVE LIMONIUM WILL BE OBSERVED WITHIN THE PROJECT AREA BETWEEN 2023, WHEN THE BASELINE INVENTORY IS COMPLETE, AND JUNE 2025, WHEN THE EXISTING FUNDING IS EXHAUSTED. SOLARIZED OCCURRENCES WILL ACHIEVE 100  MORTALITY OF NONNATIVE LIMONIUM WHILE HAND-PULLED OCCURRENCES WILL ACHIEVE BETWEEN 75100  MORTALITY OF NONNATIVE LIMONIUM.

THE COASTAL PROGRAM AND AUDUBON TEXAS ARE INTERESTED IN MANAGING WATERBIRD NESTING HABITAT ACROSS THE TEXAS COAST. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE NATURAL WATERBIRD NESTING SITES TO INCREASE POPULATIONS. AUDUBON WILL WORK COLLABORATIVELY WITH THE COASTAL PROGRAM TO IDENTIFY AND DEVELOP RESTORATION STRATEGIES ON 75 ACRES OF COASTAL HABITAT THAT CURRENTLY SUPPORTS ACTIVE NESTING COLONIES. SERVICES PROVIDED BY AUDUBON WILL INCLUDE HABITAT MANAGEMENT, TRAVEL FOR HABITAT MANAGEMENT, SUPPLIES (I.E., HERBICIDE, ANT BAIT, BAIT SPREADER, NATIVE PLANTS, PREDATOR REMOVAL TRAPS, AND WILDLIFE CAMERAS), SIGNAGE FOR PUBLIC AWARENESS OF MANAGED SITES, AND BOAT USE TO TRANSPORT STAFF TO MANAGED ISLANDS.

ONE OF THE MANY SPECIES KNOWN TO OCCUPY COASTAL WETLANDS IS THE FEDERALLY AND STATE THREATENED EASTERN BLACK RAIL (LATERALLUS JAMAICENSIS JAMAICENSIS). THERE IS CURRENTLY A GULF COAST-WIDE RECOVERY AND RESTORATION EFFORT TO IDENTIFY POPULATION LOCATIONS OF THE EASTERN BLACK RAIL, AND SUBSEQUENTLY DEVELOP HABITAT MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES TO CONSERVE THEIR HIGH MARSH HABITATS. A MULTI-PHASE APPROACH IS PROPOSED TO HELP ACHIEVE THE OVERALL GOAL OF IDENTIFYING, IMPLEMENTING, AND ASSESSING RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT ACTIVITIES IN OCCUPIED EASTERN BLACK RAIL HABITAT IN AREAS THAT COINCIDE WITH MAPPED OPPORTUNITIES FOR WETLAND MIGRATION WITH SEA LEVEL RISE ALONG THE SOUTHERN NATURE COAST OF FLORIDA.THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS TO IS ESTABLISH A PLAN FOR CONSERVING THE SPECIES AS OUR COASTLINE CHANGES. THIS CAN BE ACHIEVED THROUGH (1) UNDERSTANDING THE EASTERN BLACK RAILS LOCALIZED (SOUTHERN NATURE COAST) HABITAT AND MICROHABITAT, (2) CONSIDERING PROJECTED FUTURE HIGH MARSH HABITAT EXTENT LOCATION, AND (3) IDENTIFYING AND IMPLEMENTING RESTORATION MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES THAT CONSIDER THESE PROJECTIONS AS WELL AS THE RAILS LIFE HISTORY REQUIREMENTS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE SURVEYS FOR EASTERN BLACK RAILS IN IDENTIFIED HIGH MARSH AREAS OF THE SOUTHERN NATURE COAST OF FLORIDA USING CALL-BACK SURVEYS AND AUTONOMOUS RECORDING UNITS, VEGETATION SURVEYS, AND OTHER DATA COLLECTION SUCH AS WEATHER, BACKGROUND NOISE, MICROTOPOGRAPHY, HYDROLOGY INUNDATION LEVELS, AND FREQUENCY OF FLOODING. AFTER COMPLETING THE SURVEYS, SITE-SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS WILL BE DEVELOPED TO BENEFIT RAIL HABITAT IN AREAS THAT CORRESPOND WITH OCCURRENCES OF RAILS  THESE MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS WILL BE CATEGORIZED UNDER ENHANCEMENT OR RESTORATION. LASTLY, ENHANCEMENT AND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES WILL BE IMPLEMENTED AND SURVEYS WILL CONTINUE FOR MONITORING OF THE SPECIES.

THE KIANI UPLAND FOREST IS ONLY ONE OF ONLY TWO SITES WITHIN THE VIEQUES NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE WHERE THE FEDERALLY-LISTED STAHLIA MONOSPERMA CAN BE FOUND, A SPECIES LISTED AS THREATENED IN 1990  THE RECOVERY PLAN WAS FINALIZED IN 1996.OBJECTIVESASSESS 97 ACRES AT KIANI LAGOON TO DETERMINE HYDROLOGICAL IMPACTS, AND EVALUATE THE MANGROVE FOREST S CONDITION, INCLUDING MORTALITY AND NEW GROWTH ABOUT THE IMPORTANCE OF MANGROVES, AND THE RECOVERY OF KIANI LAGOON.VIEQUENSE YOUTH WITH HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE IN MANGROVE RESTORATION, FIELD AND GREENHOUSE WORK.PROJECT PARTNERSTHE VIEQUES CONSERVATION AND HISTORICAL TRUST (VCHT)PROJECT MANAGER, FINANCIAL ADMINISTRATOR. PROVIDES A BIOLOGIST, TECHNICAL EXPERTISE IN MANGROVE REFORESTATION, NURSERY FOR MANGROVE PROPAGATION. THIS PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT RIPARIAN RESTORATION AT THE SOUTH JACOBY WETLAND PROJECT SITE IN ARCATA, CALIFORNIA. IMPLEMENTATION WILL INCLUDE ESTABLISHING RIPARIAN PLANTING AREAS (PLANTING ISLANDS) ALONG THE FRINGE OF THE WETLAND, WHICH WILL BE PLANTED WITH NATIVE DECIDUOUS TREES AND SHRUBS AND PROTECTED WITH DEER FENCING AROUND EACH OF THE PLANTING SITES. A TOTAL OF 100 RIPARIAN PLANTS WILL BE PLANTED IN APPROXIMATELY 5-6 PLANTING SITES, COVERING A TOTAL OF 2.5 ACRES. THIS PROJECT WILL BE IMPLEMENTED BY THE CITY OF ARCATA AND THE COASTAL PROGRAM BIOLOGIST, WITH ASSISTANCE THROUGH VOLUNTEER LABOR FROM ARCATA SCOUTS BSA TROOP 15. THIS PROJECT IS A COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE CITY OF ARCATA AND THE SERVICES COASTAL PROGRAM. THE SERVICE WILL BE SUBSTANTIALLY INVOLVED THROUGH ASSISTANCE WITH PROJECT REGULATORY COMPLIANCE, PROJECT PLANNING, AND ON-THE-GROUND PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION ASSISTANCE.PROJECT GOALS ARE TO RESTORE AND PROTECT 2.5 ACRES OF RIPARIAN HABITAT WITHIN THE SOUTH JACOBY WETLAND PROJECT AREA. PROJECT OBJECTIVES INCLUDE PLANTING 100 NATIVE TREES AND SHRUBS IN APPROXIMATELY 5-6 PLANTING SITES. THESE SITES WILL BE LOCATED ALONG THE WESTERN SIDE OF THE SOUTH JACOBY WETLAND AREA AND EACH PLANTING SITE WILL BE PROTECTED WITH DEER EXCLUSIONARY FENCING TO MINIMIZE ANY POTENTIAL DEER BROWSE ON THE PLANTED VEGETATION. ADDITIONAL OBJECTIVES INCLUDE FACILITATING VOLUNTEER WORKDAYS FOR A LOCAL SCOUTS BSA TROOP, WHICH WILL PROVIDE CONSERVATION SERVICE PROJECT AND RIPARIAN RESTORATION TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES FOR LOCAL YOUTH.

IN THE WESTERN HEMISPHERE, SHOREBIRD POPULATIONS CONTINUE TO DECLINE. AS A RESULT, SHOREBIRD CONSERVATION PLANSAT THE STATE, FEDERAL, AND INTERNATIONAL FLYWAY LEVELS ALL INCLUDE RECOMMENDED ACTIONS TO CURTAIL DECLINES. WHILESOME THREATS ARE LOCALIZED, MOST OCCUR AT THE LANDSCAPE LEVEL, WITH INSUFFICIENT HABITAT QUALITY AND QUANTITYUBIQUITOUSLY CITED AS THE PRIMARY CAUSE. SHOREBIRD SPECIES VARY CONSIDERABLY IN THEIR HABITAT, DIET, ANDMIGRATORY NEEDS, AND THUS THEY RESPOND DIFFERENTLY WHEN THERE ARE CHANGES IN THE ENVIRONMENT  ESPECIALLY THEIRHABITAT. CONSISTENT MONITORING OF VARIOUS HABITAT USE IS CRITICAL TO UNDERSTANDING HOW BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICESARE AFFECTING POPULATIONS, AND NECESSARY TO DEVELOP AND DELIVER OUTREACH ON HOW MANAGEMENT PRACTICES BENEFITSHOREBIRDS. WE PROPOSE TO BRIDGE THE GAP BETWEEN SHOREBIRD CONSERVATION INTENTIONS AND IMPLEMENTATION THROUGH THE ASSESSING SHOREBIRD HABITAT NEEDS AND OPPORTUNITIES IN TEXAS INITIATIVE.  THE INITIATIVE WILL WORK TO INTEGRATESHOREBIRD HABITAT MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES INTO UPCOMING PROJECTS ON A RANGE OF PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS THROUGHTARGETED OUTREACH AND ENGAGEMENT (INCLUDING CONSERVATION PROPERTIES AS WELL AS AGRICULTURAL RANCH LANDS), ANDPROVIDE COMPREHENSIVE MONITORING TO ASSESS SHOREBIRD UTILIZATION, FOCUSING ON SHALLOW-WATER WETLANDS AND COASTALGRASSLANDS FOLLOWING PRESCRIBED FIRES. THE PROJECT HAS FOUR MAIN OBJECTIVES: (1) ASSESS THE EXTENT TO WHICHFRESHWATER WETLAND HABITAT DELIVERY PROGRAMS BENEFIT SHOREBIRDS THROUGH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF A MONITORINGFRAMEWORK  (2) ASSESS USAGE OF EARLY SUCCESSIONAL POST-FIRE LANDSCAPES BY MIGRATORY SHOREBIRDS  (3) MANAGE ANDMONITOR WETLANDS AND GRASSLANDS OF THE NUECES DELTA USING DELIBERATE BMPS TO ENHANCE SHOREBIRD USE  AND (4)DEVELOP AND DELIVER OUTREACH ON HOW MANAGEMENT PRACTICES BENEFIT SHOREBIRDS. THE ULTIMATE RESULT OF THE PROJECTWILL BE THE IDENTIFICATION OF BMPS RELATED TO WETLAND MANAGEMENT AND PRESCRIBED FIRE THAT BENEFIT UPLANDSHOREBIRDS, INCLUDING RECOMMENDATIONS FOR HOW USFWS AND OTHER PARTNERS CAN INCORPORATE THESE INTO EXISTING ANDPLANNED HABITAT DELIVERY PROGRAMS.

AMTRAK HAS A FOCUS ON MAKING RAIL-LINE UPGRADES BETWEEN NEW HAVEN (CONNECTICUT) AND RHODE ISLAND. A WORK-PLAN FOR THE NEXT FIVE YEARS IS STILL BEING DETERMINED BY AMTRAK FROM WHICH THE SERVICE WILL CONDUCT MODELING AND ANALYSIS TO RECOMMEND OPENING SIZES THAT OPTIMIZE TIDE PROPAGATION (AS TO REDUCE PONDING ON THE MARSHES UPSTREAM), REDUCE VELOCITIES (TO AID IN FISH PASSAGE) AND POTENTIALLY REDUCE THE AMOUNT OF ARMORING NEEDED BY AMTRAK. A SECONDARY FACTOR IS RESIDENCE TIME FOR FLOOD WATER UPSTREAM (REDUCING CATASTROPHIC FAILURE) SUCH THAT THE RESTORATION WILL NOT NEGATIVELY IMPACT UPSTREAM RESIDENCE. SOME WATERSHEDS WITH PROPOSED AMTRAK UPGRADES WILL HAVE PLENTY OF DATA, WHILE OTHERS WILL NOT HAVE MUCH DATA. THE PROJECT TEAM (SERVICE AND LSU) WILL MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS BASED ON MODELING AND DATA ANALYTICS FOR BOTH SCENARIOS OF DATA-RICH AND DATA-SCARCE WATERSHEDS. APPROACH: THE PROJECT WILL BEGIN WITH NUMERICAL MODELING (CONDUCTED BY LSU) OF SALT MEADOW SBM NWR, WHICH IS THE WATERSHED WITH THE MOST HYDROGRAPHIC DATA. DATA ANALYTICS WILL BE APPLIED TO GENERALIZE THE HYDRODYNAMICS AS A FUNCTION OF WATERSHED CHARACTERISTICS AND OPENING SIZE. THE DATA ANALYTICS WILL BE USED TO INFORM THE NUMERICAL MODELING FOR WATERSHEDS LACKING DATA. MODELING WILL BE APPLIED TO THE OTHER WATERSHEDS WITH THE DATA-ANALYTIC INFORMATION FILLING THE DATA GAPS. ENGINEERING AND DESIGN: THE TEAM WILL INVESTIGATE SCENARIOS OF NORMAL TIDAL CONDITIONS (QUIESCENT PERIOD), HIGH-FREQUENCY EVENTS (1025 YEAR RETURN PERIOD) AND EXTREME EVENTS (100 YEAR RETURN PERIOD). ADDITIONAL SCENARIOS WILL INVOLVE SEA-LEVEL RISE WITHIN THE DESIGN LIFE OF THE ENGINEERING WORKS (50 YEARS). DESIGN WILL INVOLVE OPTIMIZING THE OPENING SIZE ON THE BASIS OF TIDAL FLOW EXCHANGE, THRESHOLD VELOCITIES AND UPSTREAM WATER LEVELS. THE PROJECT WILL DELIVER RECOMMENDATIONS OF OPENING SIZES (UTILIZING HYDRODYNAMIC MODELING) AT DESIGNATED SITES ALONG THE AMTRAK LINE IN CT AND RI. THE NUMBER OF SITES WILL BE FOUR TO FIVE WATERSHEDS, INCLUDING SALT MEADOW SBM NWR (CT) AND PAWCATUCK RIVER (RI). TWO PARAMETERS WILL GUIDE THE RECOMMENDATION OF OPENING SIZE: THE TOP PRIORITY IS TO ESTABLISH OF TIDAL FLOW EXCHANGE  AND THE SECONDARY PRIORITY IS TO MINIMIZE UPSTREAM IMPACTS. DATA WILL BE COLLECTED AT THE SITES BY USFWS STAFF (REFUGE AND COASTAL PROGRAMS), WHICH INCLUDE: WATER LEVELS, ELEVATION, BATHYMETRY, AND VELOCITY. THE FINAL MODELING RESULTS ARE FOR FUTURE PLANNING AND DESIGN PURPOSES, IN-CONJUNCTION WITH AMTRAK AND THE PROJECT TEAM.

NORTH SHORE COMMUNITY LAND TRUST (NSCLT) AND JAMES CAMPBELL NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (JCNWR) WITH THE SUPPORT OF USFW COASTAL PROGRAM WILL ENHANCE AND EXPAND LANDSCAPE-SCALE RESTORATION ON OAHUS NORTH SHORE BY INCREASING BOTH ORGANIZATIONS CAPACITY. THE TWO ORGANIZATIONS MANAGE AND PROTECT LAND ALONG OAHU S NORTH SHORE WHICH HAS SOME OF THE MOST INTACT COASTAL AND WETLAND ECOSYSTEMS ON OAHU. ONE FULL TIME EMPLOYEE WILL BE HIRED FOR A MINIMUM OF TWO YEARS STARTING IN OCTOBER 2023. THIS POSITION WILL BE SHARED BETWEEN THE TWO ORGANIZATIONS TO PROVIDE ADDITIONAL CAPACITY THAT CAN ACCELERATE AND ENHANCE RESTORATION EFFORTS AT WAIALEE, KALAEOKAUNAOA, AND VARIOUS REFUGE LOCATIONS ON THE ISLAND OF OAHU. THIS SHARED POSITION WILL ALSO HELP THE TWO ORGANIZATIONS LEARN FROM EACH OTHER TO IMPROVE RESTORATION BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES.THE EMPLOYEE WILL FOCUS ON INVASIVE PLANT TREE REMOVAL, PREDATOR CONTROL, NATIVE OUTPLANTING, NATIVE PLANT PROPAGATION, SEED COLLECTION, THREAT IDENTIFICATION AND MANAGEMENT, VOLUNTEER OUTREACH COORDINATION, NSCLT AND REFUGE PARTNERSHIP COORDINATION REFLECTION, AND ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION.  THE EMPLOYEES TIME WILL BE SHARED  50 50 BETWEEN THE TWO ORGANIZATIONS WITH FLEXIBLIITY WHEN SPECIFIC TASKS REQUIRE ADDITIONAL TIME AT SPECIFIC LOCATIONS. THE BI-WEEKLY WORK WEEK WILL BE SPLIT UP IN THE FOLLOWING WAY, 3 DAYS WITH ONE ORGANIZATION AND 2 DAYS AT THE OTHER IN AN ALTERNATING ROTATION. (EXAMPLE WEEK 1 - MONDAY WEDNESDAY FRIDAY WITH NSCLT, TUEDAY, THURSDAY WITH REFUGE WEEK 2  MONDAY WEDNESDAY FRIDAY WITH REFUGE, TUESDAY THURSDAY WITH NSCLT). ACTUAL DAYS OF THE WEEK MAY VARY BUT NUMBER OF DAYS WOULD STAY CONSISTENT. THE EMPLOYEE WILL NEED TO WORK NSCLTS COMMUNITY VOLUNTEER EVENTS WHICH ARE HELD ON SATURDAYS. TO OFFSET EXTRA HOURS THE EMPLOYEE WILL BE ALLOWED TO WORK A SHORTENED WORKDAY FOR NSCLT ON EITHER THE FRIDAY LEADING UP TO THE COMMUNITY VOLUNTEER DAY OR THE MONDAY AFTER THE EVENT.THE EMPLOYEE WILL REGULARLY DOCUMENT AND SHARE INFORMATION BETWEEN ORGANIZATIONS REGARDING POTENTIALLY SHARED STRATEGIES, PROTOCOLS, AND COLLABORATIVE OPPORTUNITIES. THIS INCLUDES PLANNING AND FACILITATING A JOINT UPDATE MEETING AT LEAST BIANNUALLY. THE EMPLOYEE WILL ALSO ORGANIZE THREE ANNUAL JOINT WORKDAYS, ONE EACH AT WAIALEE, KALAEOKAUNAOA, AND JAMES CAMPBELL NWR. THEY WILL ADDITIONALLY PAY CLOSE ATTENTION TO HABITAT RESTORATION EFFORTS AND OFFER ADVICE ON PROPAGATION AND OUTPLANTING OF NATIVE SPECIES, INCLUDING APPROPRIATENESS AND SPECIES COMPOSITION.PACIFIC ISLANDS COASTAL PROGRAM PERSONNEL WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE BY HELPING TO SELECT AND TRAIN THE EMPLOYEE AND BY COORDINATING WITH NSCLT AND JCNWR TO MAXIMIZE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE POSITION.

IN JULY 2021, THE DELMARVA RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION NETWORK (DRCN) COMPLETED A STRATEGIC RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION ACTION PLAN (ACTION PLAN), WHICH OUTLINED A CONCEPT DESIGN FOR DELMARVA CONSERVATION. THE NEXT PHASE OF IMPLEMENTATION IS THE DEVELOPMENT OF A SPECIFIC LAND PROTECTION PLAN THROUGH THE FURTHER ENGAGEMENT OF THE DRCN AND ITS VARIOUS GOVERNMENTAL AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL PARTNERS. THE EASTERN SHORE LAND CONSERVANCY (ESLC) WILL WORK WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, AND OTHER DELMARVA-FOCUSED CONSERVATION GROUPS TO DEVELOP A COMPREHENSIVE, REGION-WIDE CONSERVATION PLAN THAT WILL IDENTIFY SPECIFIC AREAS FOR PRIORITY CONSERVATION ACTIVITY, INCLUDING RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION EASEMENTS. THIS PROJECT WOULD HELP TO ENSURE A NET-GAIN INCREASE IN PROTECTED PRIORITY WILDLIFE HABITAT AND MIGRATION CORRIDORS IN THE DELMARVA IN THE FACE OF THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE. SUCH A PLAN WOULD ALLOW FEDERAL, STATE, LOCAL, AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL CONSERVATION FUNDING TO BE TARGETED TO THE HIGHEST REGIONAL CONSERVATION PRIORITIES.

INVESTMENT IN THE PROJECT WILL BUILD UPON WORK CONDUCTED UNDER COOPERATIVEAGREEMENTS  F18AC00777 AND  F22AC01137-00, WHERE INVASIVE SPECIES TREATMENT WAS CONDUCTED TO REDUCEPOPULATIONS OF INVASIVE GLOSSY BUCKTHORN TO LEVELS MANAGEABLE BY THE MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES(MDNR). A COMPREHENSIVE BOTANICAL SURVEY FOR PSGA WILL BE COMPLETED THROUGH THE SCOPE OF  F22AC01137-00 ANDSIMILAR DATA IS ALREADY AVAILABLE FOR MBNA. PROJECT PARTNERS WILL INSTALL FENCING AND SIGNAGE TO GUIDE VISITOR ACCESSTHROUGH SENSITIVE DUNE HABITAT AND PROTECT KNOWN POPULATIONS OF RARE AND THREATENED SPECIES. ADDITIONALLY, LOCALLYSOURCED NATIVE PLANTS WILL BE USED TO RESTORE EROSION SITES AND MITIGATE IMPACTS OF HUMAN DISTURBANCE.PSGA AND THE ADJACENT MAPLE BAY NATURAL AREA CREATE ROUGHLY 1.8 MILES OF CONTIGUOUS SHORELINE ALONG THE EAST ARM OFGRAND TRAVERSE BAY. BOTH THE FEDERALLY THREATENED PITCHERS THISTLE (CIRSIUM PITCHERI) AND STATE THREATENED LAKE HURONTANSY (TANACETUM HURONENSE) ARE KNOWN TO OCCUR AT THESE SITES.ACTIVITIES: FUNDING OF THIS PROPOSAL WILL ALLOW THE GRAND TRAVERSE REGIONAL LAND CONSERVANCY (GTRLC) TO HIRE SEEDSYOUTH CONSERVATION CORPS TO BUILD AND INSTALL UP TO 4200-FT OF CABLE FENCING TO GUIDE VISITORS AROUND THE MOST HEAVILYIMPACTED AREAS AT MBNA AND PSGA. GTRLC WILL SUPPORT THESE PROTECTION EFFORTS BY DEVELOPING SIGNAGE DISCUSSING THESENSITIVE DUNE HABITAT AND SPECIES FOUND WITHIN.BUILDING ON THE SUCCESS OF VOLUNTEER WORKDAYS AT MBNA AND PSGA, GTRLC WILL HOST 3 WORKDAYS TARGETING INVASIVESPECIES ON 11 ACRES OF RELATIVELY PRISTINE COASTAL DUNE HABITAT FOUND AT MBNA AND PSGA. TARGET SPECIES WILL INCLUDESPOTTED KNAPWEED AND BLADDER CAMPION WHICH DIRECTLY COMPETE WITH LAKE HURON TANSY AND PITCHER S THISTLE AT THESITE.HIGH-TRAFFIC AND EROSION PRONE AREAS WILL BE RESTORED USING LOCALLY SOURCED NATIVE PLANTS THROUGH THE USE OF VOLUNTEERWORKDAYS. IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT 2-4 WORKDAYS WILL BE NEEDED TO COMPLETE THIS WORK.OUTCOMES: GUIDING USER ACCESS TO THE PROPERTY THROUGH THE USE OF A CABLE FENCING SYSTEM AND BLOCKING OF SOCIAL TRAILSWILL LIMIT DISTURBANCE TO POPULATIONS OF RARE AND THREATENED SPECIES. NATIVE DUNE SPECIES, PRIMARILY GRASSES, WILL BE USEDTO RESTORE AND STABILIZE HIGHLY ERODED AREAS THROUGHOUT THE SITE. WORKDAYS WILL CONTINUE AT THESE SITES ENSURE THE RARESPECIES LOCATED IN THESE COASTAL DUNE HABITATS ARE FREE FROM THE COMPETITIVE PRESSURE OF INVASIVE SPECIES. COMBINEDWITH THE PROPOSED RESTORATION ACTIVITIES, THESE EFFORTS WILL RESULT IN IMPROVED HABITAT CONNECTIVITY IN THE REGION ANDPROVIDE CRITICAL WILDLIFE CORRIDORS.CONTINUED RESTORATION AND PROTECTION OF MAPLE BAY NATURAL AREA AND PETOBEGO STATE GAME AREA TO MEET THE HABITATREQUIREMENTS OF THREATENED PLANTS WILL RESULT IN HEALTHY, FUNCTIONAL ECOSYSTEMS THAT ARE CAPABLE OF SUPPORTING A RANGEOF WILDLIFE AND THE NATURAL RESOURCES THAT LOCAL COMMUNITY MEMBERS DEPEND ON. FURTHERMORE, THE PROJECT AREAREPRESENTS THE NORTHERN EXTENT FOR SOME OF THESE SPECIES IN MICHIGAN AND RESTORATION WILL PARTICULARLY BENEFIT THOSE ATRISKPOPULATIONS.THE PROJECT WILL ALSO MAINTAIN AND BUILD UPON CURRENT COLLABORATION AND COOPERATION BETWEEN USFWS, MDNR, ANDGTRLC, DEMONSTRATING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF PROJECTS ENGAGING STAKEHOLDERS AT THE FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL LEVEL. THEINCLUSION OF GRAND TRAVERSE COUNTY AS A NEW PROJECT PARTNER ADVANCES THE SCOPE OF COLLABORATION FOR THIS PROJECT AREA.

THIS PROJECT WILL PROTECT AND PRESERVE THE NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES OF THE HANA MOKU, AND PRESERVE AND MANAGE THE AREA S NATURAL, CULTURAL SCENIC, HISTORIC, AND MARINE RESOURCES. THE GOAL IS TO DELINEATE AND PROTECT A NEW WILDLIFE HABITAT CONSERVATION AREA AT MAKAALAE WITH A FENCE TO EXCLUDE CATTLE, PLANT COASTAL NATIVE PLANTS TO IMPROVE FORAGING FOR HYLAEUS ANTHRICINUS AND IMPLEMENT BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR MONITORING THREATENED PLANTS AND WILDLIFE. THE FENCE WILL BE CONSTRUCTED BY THE DIVISION OF FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE AND WILL PREVENT CATTLE FROM ENTERING THE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AREA FROM THE ADJACENT PASTURE. COASTAL NATIVE PLANTS WILL BE SOURCED FROM THE REGION AND GROWN AT A LOCAL NURSERY ON MAUI. WHEN THEY REACH PLANTING SIZE, THE PROJECT STAFF WILL INSPECT THE PLANTS AND OUTPLANT THEM ON SITE WITH COMMUNITY STEWARDS AND LOCAL VOLUNTEERS. COASTAL PROGRAM STAFF WILL BE SIGNIFICANTLY INVOLVED BY 1) USING DATA FROM ONGOING RESEARCH ON YELLOW-FACED BEES TO INFORM PLANT SELECTION FOR OUT-PLANTING AND 2) ASSISTING IN SEED COLLECTION AND OR OUT-PLANTING ON-SITE.

GREENTRUST ALLIANCE WILL OVERSEE, WITH KEY SERVICE OVERSIGHT, ALL INVESTIGATIONS AND PREPARATIONS RELATED TO THEIMPLEMENTATION OF THE GREEN BROOK MITIGATION PROJECT INCLUDING PLANNING AND SITE PREPARATION, AND SOME PLANTINGAND SEEDING TASKS. ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE COORDINATION ON OPPORTUNITIES TO PROMOTE AND ENHANCE HABITAT FOR ATRISKSPECIES  INCREASED RESILIENCE TO CLIMATE CHANGE  AND IMPROVED HABITAT FOR TERRESTRIAL ANIMALS.THIS SCOPE HELPS ADVANCE THE ULTIMATE DEVELOPMENT OF APPROXIMATELY 41.82 WETLAND MITIGATION UNITS AND 13.45RIPARIAN ZONE UNITS. TOWARDS THAT END, THIS SCOPE INCLUDES FINAL PRE-CONSTRUCTION COORDINATION WITH REGULATORYAGENCIES AND LANDOWNERS, IMPLEMENTATION OF SOME EROSION CONTROL AND TEMPORARY DEER AND GOOSE EXCLUSION FENCINGEFFORTS, PREPARATION OF SOME PROJECT AREAS FOR PLANTING, AND PLANTING AND SEEDING OF SOME AREAS OF THE PROJECT.

SALT MARSHES ALONG THE US COASTLINE ARE CRUCIAL FOR PRIMARY PRODUCTIVITY, BIODIVERSITY, AND ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, BUT THEY ARE FACING THREATS SUCH AS POLLUTION, DEVELOPMENT, ALTERED HYDROLOGY, AND RISING SEA LEVELS. HIGH MARSH HABITATS, CHARACTERIZED BY HIGH SALINITY SOILS AND UNIQUE WETLAND PLANT SPECIES, ARE PARTICULARLY VULNERABLE. THESE HABITATS ARE ESSENTIAL FOR THE EASTERN BLACK RAIL (LATERALLUS JAMAICENSIS JAMAICENSIS), A THREATENED SPECIES LISTED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. MANAGEMENT PRACTICES IN COASTAL TEXAS MARSHES RELY ON PRESCRIBED FIRE, HERBICIDES, MECHANICAL TREATMENTS, AND GRAZING TO MAINTAIN HIGH SALT MARSH HABITAT. HOWEVER, THE SPECIFIC EFFECTS OF THESE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS ON BLACK RAIL POPULATIONS ARE NOT WELL UNDERSTOOD. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INVESTIGATE HOW DIFFERENT MANAGEMENT TREATMENTS IMPACT BLACK RAIL POPULATIONS IN COASTAL TEXAS MARSHES. THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO STUDY THE RESPONSE EFFECTS OF DIFFERENT TREATMENT METHODS ON BLACK RAIL POPULATIONS, DEVELOP SCIENCE-BASED RECOMMENDATIONS FOR HABITAT MANAGERS, AND ENGAGE WITH LOCAL LANDOWNERS AND STAKEHOLDERS TO PROMOTE THE CONSERVATION OF BLACK RAIL POPULATIONS AND MARSH ECOSYSTEMS. THE PROJECT WILL BE CONDUCTED AT THE TEXAS MID-COAST NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (NWR) COMPLEX REFUGES, GORDY MARSH, AND THE FROST DEAN TRACT. THE PROJECT WILL INVOLVE DEPLOYING AUTONOMOUS RECORDING UNITS (ARUS) TO DETERMINE WHEN BLACK RAILS RECOLONIZE TREATED AREAS. STEM DENSITY AND ABOVE-GROUND BIOMASS OF VEGETATION WILL BE MEASURED, AND LANDSCAPE-LEVEL METRICS WILL BE ASSESSED. OCCUPANCY AND DETECTION PROBABILITIES WILL BE MODELED USING STATISTICAL TECHNIQUES TO ANALYZE THE DATA. THE PROJECT WILL BE CONDUCTED OVER FOUR YEARS, WITH ACTIVITIES INCLUDING FIELDWORK, DATA ANALYSIS, AND REPORTING. REGULAR COMMUNICATION WITH PROJECT PARTNERS AND STAKEHOLDERS WILL BE MAINTAINED THROUGH MEETINGS, PROGRESS REPORTS, AND FINAL EVALUATIONS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL INCLUDE DR. CHRIS BUTLER AS THE PI, A GRADUATE STUDENT, AND TWO FIELD TECHNICIANS. PROJECT OVERSIGHT WILL BE PROVIDED BY US FISH   WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) COASTAL PROGRAM AND THE TEXAS MID-COAST NWR COMPLEX. THE RESULTS WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE CONSERVATION AND SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT OF BLACK RAIL POPULATIONS AND THE OVERALL HEALTH OF MARSH ECOSYSTEMS IN THE REGION.

HARRISIA ABORIGINUM WAS LISTED AS ENDANGERED IN 2013. CRITICAL HABITAT WAS DESIGNATED IN 2016 AT WHICH TIME ONLY 300 TO 500 INDIVIDUALS AND 12 POPULATIONS WERE KNOWN TO EXIST (USFWS 2016). SINCE 2019, MSBG HAS BEEN SURVEYING KNOWN POPULATIONS AND ASSESSING SURROUNDING HABITAT. THESE POPULATIONS ARE ALL AT RISK FROM INVASIVE AND WOODY SPECIES ENCROACHMENT, DEVELOPMENT, STORMS, AND SEA LEVEL RISE. TO IMPROVE HABITAT OF EXISTING POPULATIONS AS WELL AS TO CREATE NEW HABITAT FOR TRANSLOCATIONS, WE PROPOSE A COORDINATED EFFORT TO RESTORE AND MAINTAIN H. ABORIGINUM HABITAT, IMPROVE CONDITIONS AT KNOWN EXTANT SITES WITH PARTICULAR FOCUS ON HISTORIC STRONGHOLDS, AND CONDUCT POPULATION INTRODUCTIONS AND AUGMENTATIONS OVER THE NEXT FIVE YEARS ON PROTECTED LANDS, BEGINNING WITH SARASOTA COUNTY.

THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, NEW JERSEY FIELD OFFICE (SERVICE) AND THE CONSERVE WILDLIFE FOUNDATION OF NEW JERSEY (CWF) ARE ENTERING INTO A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT THROUGH WHICH CWF WILL ASSIST THE SERVICE IN COMPLETING AT LEAST 10 MUNICIPAL BEACH MANAGEMENT PLANS AS WELL AS SURVEYING FOR BIRDS, HERPTILES, AND MAMMALS  AND RESTORING APPROXIMATELY 200 ACRES OF HABITAT FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE USING INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL, GRASSLAND RESTORATION, AND WETLAND ENHANCEMENT IN THE PINELANDS, INCLUDING WITHIN THE JOINT BASE MCGUIRE-DIX-LAKEHURST (JBMDL).

ERADICATION OF RATS AND RODENTS, AS WELL AS OTHER INVASIVE SPECIES IN ISLAND ECOSYSTEMS HAS BEEN PROVEN TO BE THE MOST EFFECTIVE ACTION TO RESTORE ISLAND ECOSYSTEMS. THERE IS A BODY OF 30 YEARS OF WORK AND OVER 900 PROJECTS BY ISLAND CONSERVATION, EER AND OTHERS THAT HAS DEMONSTRATED THE SUCCESS OF THIS APPROACH.  WHEN RODENTS OR OTHER INVASIVE VERTEBRATES ARE ERADICATED NATURE BRINGS BACK THE ECOSYSTEMS ON THE ISLANDS.  PLANTS, BIRDS AND OTHER SPECIES REPOPULATE THE ISLANDS, INCLUDING ENDANGERED AND THREATENED LISTED SPECIES AND CANDIDATE SPECIES. ERADICATION OF RATS FROM SEVERAL ISLANDS IN PUERTO RICO AND THE U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS BY DNER, U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS (USVI) DEPARTMENT OF PLANNING AND NATURAL RESOURCES (DPNR), AND OTHER ORGANIZATIONS HAS ENABLED SIGNIFICANT RECOVERY, TO THE U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS TREE BOA AND SEVERAL SEABIRDS (PIERCE 2007  TOLSON ET AL. 2008).  EER HAS HAD EXCELLENT SUCCESS IN PREVIOUS ERADICATION PROJECTS ON OTHERS COASTAL HABITAT.  FOR EXAMPLE, IN 2010 IN RATONES AND CARDONA ISLANDS, IN 2015 IN ISLA DEL FRIO, IN 2018 IN CAYO LOBO NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE IN CULEBRA, AMONG OTHERS.  THIS LAST ONE IN AN IMPORTANT BREEDING AREA FOR THE AUDUBON SHEARWATER.THE PROJECT ERADICATION OF BLACK RATS (RATTUS RATTUS) ON BERBERA CAY PROJECTS LONG TERM GOAL IS TO RESTORE THIS COASTAL HABITAT THROUGH THE ERADICATION OF INVASIVE BLACK RATS AND GREEN IGUANAS ON THIS SMALL CAY IN SOUTHERN P.R.  AS A RESULT, BIRDS, REPTILES, INVERTEBRATES, AND PLANT LIFE WILL COME BACK TO THE CAY AND THE ECOSYSTEM WILL BE RESTORED.  A LONG-TERM MONITORING STUDY OF THE EFFECTS OF THE RAT ERADICATION ON THE CAYS BIODIVERSITY WILL BE DONE TO DEMONSTRATE SUCCESS.

IN THE COQUILLE WATERSHED, LESS THAN 5  OF THE HISTORIC TIDAL WETLANDS REMAIN. LACK OF SLOW-WATER REFUGIA AND OFF-CHANNEL HABITAT HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED AS A CRITICAL LIMITING FACTOR AFFECTING OREGON COAST ESU COHO RECOVERY. THE LESLIE WETLAND RESERVE IS A 50 ACRE TIDALLY INFLUENCED WETLAND RESERVE UNDER A NRCS CONSERVATION EASEMENT IN PERPETUITY IN COQUILLE, OR (COOS COUNTY). A RESTORATION PROJECT IN THE 1990S ATTEMPTED TO REVERT THE 50 ACRES OF BOTTOMLAND FROM PASTURELAND TO THE HISTORIC WETLAND STATE BY REMOVAL OF TIDE GATES AND DRAINAGE DITCHES. THE MAJORITY OF THE EASEMENT, INCLUDING THE ALLUVIAL FLOODPLAIN, IS STILL IN POOR CONDITION AND ALMOST ENTIRELY LACKS WETLAND FUNCTION. COQWA HAS PREVIOUSLY RECEIVED FUNDING FROM OWEB AND THE WILD RIVERS COAST ALLIANCE TO PURSUE DATA COLLECTION AND BEGIN THE DESIGN PROCESS THAT WILL ADDRESS THE FOLLOWING ISSUES: 1) LACK OF FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY DUE TO AN INCISED CHANNEL  2) HYDROLOGICAL CONSTRICTIONS ABOVE AND BELOW THE FLOODPLAIN DUE TO UNDERSIZED CULVERTS  AND 3) LACK OF NATIVE PLANT DIVERSITY AND A MONOCULTURE OF REED CANARY GRASS. THIS SOLICITATION WILL FUND FINAL RESTORATION DESIGNS FOR THE INTERIOR WETLAND AND BRIDGE DESIGNS FOR FISH PASSAGE, PERMITTING, A PLANTING PLAN, AND MONITORING PLAN. COQWA WILL CONTINUE TO PARTNER WITH THE LANDOWNERS, COQUILLE INDIAN TRIBE, USFWS, ODFW, USFS, NRCS, AND COOS COUNTY AMONG OTHER INTERESTED RESTORATION PRACTITIONERS TO DEVELOP A SUITE OF ACTIONS TO REACH OUR GOALS.

THE PARTNERSHIP FOR GULF COAST LAND CONSERVATION, INC. (GULF PARTNERSHIP) HAS BEEN IMPLEMENTING A PROJECT ASSISTANCE PROGRAM THAT PROVIDES SMALL CATALYST GRANTS TO REGIONAL CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS, WHICH IN TURN ALLOWS FOR THE LEVERAGING OF OTHER PARTNERS FUNDING SOURCES TO BUILD REGIONAL CAPACITY FOR CONSERVATION. THIS PROGRAM PROVIDES UP-FRONT DUE DILIGENCE FOR THE ACQUISITION EASEMENT OF GULF CONSERVATION LANDS THAT ALIGN WITH REGIONAL PARTNER PRIORITIES AND THE STRATEGIC CONSERVATION VISION MAPPING TOOL TO PERMANENTLY PROTECT FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES AND THEIR CRITICAL HABITATS ACROSS THE GULF COAST.SINCE ITS INCEPTION IN 2014, THE GULF PARTNERSHIP AWARDED  414,000 AND LEVERAGED NEARLY  87,000,000 IN MATCH SUPPORT, WHERE ADDITIONAL FUNDING WILL HAVE THE ABILITY TO SERVE AS A FURTHER CATALYST FOR REGIONAL CONSERVATION. THE GULF PARTNERSHIP IS REQUESTING AN ADDITIONAL  60,000 IN FUNDING, WHERE SUBAWARD PARTNERS WILL BE PROVIDED DUE-DILIGENCE SUPPORT FOR IMPLEMENTING FEE ACQUISITION OR CONSERVATION EASEMENT PROJECTS TO COMPLETE APPRAISALS, APPRAISAL REVIEWS, TITLE EXAMS, ENVIRONMENTAL AND BASELINE STUDIES, SURVEYS, CLOSINGS, AND OTHER DUE DILIGENCE AS NECESSARY. THROUGH THIS PROGRAM, THE GULF PARTNERSHIP AIMS TO PROTECT AN ADDITIONAL 200 ACRES, LEVERAGING LIMITED CONSERVATION DOLLARS WHILE WORKING COLLECTIVELY WITH REGIONAL PARTNERS TO IDENTIFY, DEVELOP, AND IMPLEMENT PROJECTS AT A LANDSCAPE LEVEL FOR BROADER CONSERVATION IMPACT.

GENETIC ANALYSIS IS THE CRITICAL FIRST STEP REQUIRED TO PINPOINT THE MOST EFFECTIVE HABITAT IMPROVEMENT AND RESTORATION ACTIONS THAT SHOULD BE TAKEN ACROSS THE ENTIRE RANGE OF EACH FOCAL SPECIES. THIS STRATEGY WILL PROVIDE ESSENTIAL GENETIC DATA AND ANALYSIS FOR TEN FOCAL SPECIES TO INFORM FUTURE RECOVERY ACTIONS (E.G., REINTRODUCTIONS, TRANSLOCATIONS) NEEDED TO ACHIEVE RESILIENT POPULATIONS AND TO HELP UNDERSTAND: 1) MOVEMENT ACROSS SPECIES RANGES, 2) HABITAT POPULATION CONNECTIVITY  AND 3) GENETIC DIVERSITY WITHIN SMALL, FRAGMENTED POPULATIONS. WE ENVISION THIS AS A MULTIYEAR PROJECT. HOWEVER, WE ARE CURRENTLY REQUESTING FUNDING FOR PHASE YEAR 1, DURING WHICH THE PROPOSED WORK INCLUDES THE FOLLOWING:  OBTAIN GENETIC SAMPLES OF A SUBSET OF THE TEN FOCAL SPECIES IDENTIFIED WITHIN FLORIDA AND ALABAMA IN COORDINATION WITH FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL LAND MANAGERS FOR GENOTYPING AND ANALYSIS.  GENOTYPE PKBM SAMPLES AND MONITOR GENETIC DIVERSITY IN WILD AND CAPTIVE POPULATIONS (PKBM 5-YEAR REVIEW AND DELISTING RECOVERY CRITERION 2).

THE PROPOSED WORK ON POCOSIN LAKES NWR IS HIGH PRIORITY AREA FOR BREEDING HABITAT FOR THREATENED EASTERN BLACK RAILS. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO RESTORE GLOBALLY THREATENED AWC (CHAMAECYPARIS THYOIDES) FORESTS WITHIN ITS HISTORIC RANGE . 1) THE PROPOSED WORK INCLUDES A) CREATE ELEVATION, SHALLOW WATER AND WETLAND EDGE HABITAT FOR EASTERN BLACK RAIL BREEDING HABITAT ADJACENT TO A CANAL (3 ACRES) AND TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY (GRASSY RIDGE FLOOD REDUCTION STUDY)  B) CONVERSION OF 40 ACRES OF CROPLAND TO EARLY SUCCESSIONAL EMERGENT WETLAND WITH HUMMOCKS THAT WILL PROVIDE PREFERRED HABITAT FOR BREEDING BLACK RAILS  C) CONVERSION OF 30 ACRES OF CROPLAND TO AWC FOREST. AWC SEEDLINGS WILL BE PLANTED BUILDING ON PREVIOUS RESTORATION AT 1) RESTORATION STAND PLANTED BY WEYERHAEUSER WITH SUPPORT FROM USFWS ON REFUGE IN THE EARLY 1990S AND 2) THE MILLENNIUM FOREST PLANTED BY VOLUNTEERS IN 2002. THE INTERESTED PUBLIC AND LOCAL SCHOOL CHILDREN WILL BE EDUCATED ON THE PROGRESS OF THIS WORK AND WILL ASSIST WITH LOCAL VOLUNTEER PLANTING OF AWC SEEDLINGS.

THE ROBUST PETROCHEMICAL INDUSTRY, RAPID GROWTH OF SUBURBAN POPULATIONS, AGRICULTURE, AND OTHER HUMAN INFLUENCES IN THE GREATER HOUSTON REGION HAVE PLACED INCREDIBLE STRESS ON THE NATURAL RESOURCES OF THE GALVESTON BAY ESTUARINE SYSTEM. THE ECOSYSTEM LOST MORE THAN 35,000 ACRES OF COASTAL WETLANDS SINCE THE 1950S TO SUBSIDENCE AND SHORELINE DEVELOPMENT. ADDITIONALLY, COASTAL PRAIRIE LANDSCAPES AND BOTTOMLAND HARDWOOD FORESTS HAVE BEEN ALTERED FOR AGRICULTURAL PURPOSES AND THE REMAINING HIGH-QUALITY HABITAT IS AT HIGH RISK FOR CONVERSION. LAND CONSERVATION PROVIDES ECOLOGICAL STABILITY IN A RAPIDLY CHANGING LANDSCAPE, ECOSYSTEM SERVICES FOR COASTAL COMMUNITIES, AND ECONOMIC BENEFITS TO LOCAL ECONOMIES.THE GALVESTON BAY PLAN IDENTIFIES HABITAT LOSS AS ONE OF THE GREATEST THREATS TO THE HEALTH AND PRODUCTIVITY OF GALVESTON BAY. CONSEQUENTLY, THE GALVESTON BAY PLAN IDENTIFIES HABITAT PROTECTION AS A PRIORITY ACTION FOR THE WATERSHED. LAND CONSERVATION EFFORTS TO PERPETUALLY PROTECT WETLANDS AND OTHER IMPORTANT COASTAL HABITATS WILL HELP ENSURE THE LONG-TERM HEALTH AND PRODUCTIVITY OF GALVESTON BAY. IN RESPONSE TO THESE IDENTIFIED PRIORITIES, THE GALVESTON BAY ESTUARY PROGRAM (GBEP) PARTNERED WITH GBF TO ESTABLISH AND FUND THE CONSERVATION ASSISTANCE PROGRAM (CAP). THE CAP IS INTENDED TO ADDRESS DEFICIENCIES IN LAND CONSERVATION EFFORTS IN THE GALVESTON BAY WATERSHED AND BUILD CAPACITY WITHIN REGIONAL LAND CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS.AS A RESULT OF STRONG LOCAL PARTNERSHIPS AND COORDINATION, THE CAP HAS IDENTIFIED LAND PROTECTION GOALS AND OBJECTIVES FOR THE REGION AND CONVENED A CONSERVATION WORKGROUP OF REGIONAL LAND CONSERVATION PARTNERS. THIS PROPOSED GRANT WILL UTILIZE THE EXISTING CAP WORKGROUP FRAMEWORK TO SUPPORT LOCAL LAND ACQUISITION PROJECTS BY FUNDING DUE DILIGENCE ACTIVITIES FOR ONGOING LAND PROTECTION PROJECTS. COASTAL PROGRAM FUNDING FROM THIS GRANT WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE TO PARTICIPATING LAND CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS AT CAP WORKGROUP MEETINGS. CONSENSUS FROM WORKGROUP PARTNERS WILL ENSURE THE FUNDS ARE UTILIZED TO SUPPORT REGIONAL LAND ACQUISITION PRIORITIES.CONTRACTUAL FUNDS FROM THIS GRANT WILL BE DEDICATED TO CONTRACTING WITH QUALIFIED SERVICE PROVIDERS TO COMPLETE DUE DILIGENCE ACTIVITIES RELATED TO LAND ACQUISITION PROJECTS WITHIN THE GALVESTON BAY WATERSHED. GBF WILL RELY ON CAP WORKGROUP CONSENSUS TO ALLOCATE FUNDING TO APPROVED ACTIVE PROJECTS. DUE DILIGENCE TASKS FUNDED UNDER THIS GRANT WILL PRODUCE A TANGIBLE PRODUCT, SUCH AS A PROPERTY BOUNDARY SURVEY, APPRAISAL, PHASE 1 ESA, OR OTHER REQUIRED DOCUMENTATION RELATED TO COMPLETE THE REAL ESTATE TRANSACTION. FUNDING WILL NOT BE USED TO PAY FOR STAFF TIME, PROJECT MANAGEMENT, OR CLOSING COSTS. COSTS FOR THESE SERVICES WILL VARY WIDELY DEPENDING ON THE SIZE AND COMPLEXITY OF THE PROJECT.

THROUGH THIS NEW AGREEMENT, KACHEMAK HERITAGE LAND TRUST (KHLT) MEASURABLY INCREASES THE SUPPORT AND LONG-TERM CONSERVATION OF FEDERAL TRUST RESOURCES ON ALASKAS KENAI PENINSULA. THE GOAL OF FUNDING THIS FIRST YEAR OF THE AGREEMENT IS TO CONTINUE AND BUILD UPON KACHEMAK HERITAGE LAND TRUSTS PREVIOUS WORK DESCRIBED IN USFWS F20AC00644 TO PERMANENTLY PRESERVE PRIORITY FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT THROUGH LANDOWNER CONTACT AND OUTREACH TO THE PUBLIC, PERFORMANCE OF DUE DILIGENCE ON PROPERTIES OF INTEREST, AND VOLUNTARY HABITAT PROTECTION. A QUANTITATIVE ESTIMATE OF ACREAGE WILL BE PROVIDED TO USFWS ASSOCIATED WITH THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT AS PROJECTS DEVELOP. THE GALVESTON BAY FOUNDATION OPERATES A NATIVE PLANT NURSERY THAT IS USED TO SUPPORT RESTORATION NEEDS ON CONSERVATION LANDS AROUND GALVESTON BAY. PLANTS ARE GROWN AT THE FACILITY KNOWN AS THE ECOCENTER, THEN TRANSPLANTED BY THE COMMUNITY TO ENHANCE OR CREATE NATIVE HABITAT COVER FOR WILDLIFE. FUNDING FOR THIS FACILITY WILL FACILITATE THE PROCESSES OF COLLECTING SEED, GROWING PLANTS, AND TRANSPLANTING HEALTHY NATIVE VEGETATION ON CONSERVATION LANDS BY VOLUNTEERS AND OTHER NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS.

ABSTRACT- HABITAT MANAGEMENT TECHNICIANSTHE GALVESTON BAY FOUNDATION IS AN ACCREDITED LAND TRUST THAT HAS PROTECTED MORE THAN 15,000 ACRES OFCONSERVATION LANDS IN 4 COUNTIES: GALVESTON, HARRIS, BRAZORIA, AND CHAMBERS. GBF PLANS TO HIRE TWOSEASONAL TECHNICIANS OVER A 14-WEEK TERM IN 2023. THE TECH WILL FOCUS ON HABITAT MANAGEMENT,MONITORING, AND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES ON GBFS PRESERVES THROUGHOUT THE GALVESTON BAY WATERSHED. AS ACONDITION OF THEIR EMPLOYMENT AT GBF, THE TECHNICIANS WILL UNDERGO TRAINING RELATED TO DATA COLLECTION,HABITAT MAPPING, HABITAT MANAGEMENT PLANNING, NATIVE AND INVASIVE FLORA AND FAUNA IDENTIFICATION ANDMANAGEMENT, GREENHOUSE MANAGEMENT, SMALL AND LARGE MECHANICAL EQUIPMENT OPERATION MAINTENANCE,AND VARIOUS OTHER TASKS AS NEEDS ARE IDENTIFIED.

EXCESS SEDIMENTATION IS WIDELY RECOGNIZED AS THE LARGEST NONPOINT SOURCE OF POLLUTION THREATENING AQUATIC HABITAT AND NEARSHORE WATER QUALITY IN THE CHEQUAMEGON BAY REGION OF LAKE SUPERIOR. THE FISH CREEK WATERSHED IS THE PRIMARY SOURCE OF EXCESS SEDIMENTATION DIRECTLY TO CHEQUAMEGON BAY. NORTH FISH CREEK IS DESIGNATED A CLASS I TROUT STREAM BY THE WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES. IT HAS IMPORTANT COLD-WATER HABITAT FOR NATIVE BROOK TROUT THAT IS CURRENTLY LIMITED BY EXCESS SEDIMENTATION.THE PRIMARY GOAL AND PURPOSE FOR THIS PROJECT IS TO REDUCE SEDIMENT DELIVERY AND IMPROVE AQUATIC AND RIPARIAN HABITAT FOR NATIVE BROOK TROUT AND OTHER FISH AND WILDLIFE IN NORTH FISH CREEK. A SECONDARY GOAL IS TO REDUCE SEDIMENT DELIVERY TO CHEQUAMEGON BAY OF LAKE SUPERIOR. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY STABILIZING A 480-FOOT TERRACE AND 540-FOOT UNSTABLE BLUFF THAT WILL SAVE AN ESTIMATED 1,544 TONS OF SEDIMENT ANNUALLY. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO PROTECT APPROXIMATELY 1,700 FEET (0.32 MILES) OF STREAM RIPARIAN CORRIDOR AND ENHANCE BROOK TROUT AND OTHER FISH HABITAT BY USING LARGE WOOD STRUCTURES TO ADD HABITAT COMPLEXITY AND ROUGHNESS TO A STREAM REACH SEVERELY DEGRADED FOLLOWING A FLOOD EVENT IN 2018.

THIS PROJECT WILL ASSESS THE CURRENT STATUS OF SAND DUNE PHACELIA (PHACELIA ARGENTEA) WITHIN ITS KNOWN RANGE. IN 2023, THIS PROJECT WILL REPEAT THE RANGE-WIDE SURVEY CONDUCTED IN 2017 BY THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURAL, IN ADDITION TO INVESTIGATING ADDITIONAL SITES THAT WERE NOT SURVEYED AS PART OF THAT EFFORT. SAND DUNE PHACELIA, AN EVERGREEN PERENNIAL HERB ENDEMIC TO THE COASTS OF SOUTHERN OREGON AND NORTHERN CALIFORNIA, WAS PETITIONED FOR LISTING UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT IN 2014 AND IS EXPECTED TO BE LISTED AS THREATENED IN 2023. IT IS LISTED AS THREATENED BY THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE AND AS A CALIFORNIA RARE PLANT (RANK 1B.1) BY THE CALIFORNIA NATIVE PLANT SOCIETY. THIS PROJECT WILL INFORM RECOVERY, CONSERVATION, AND HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIONS FOR SAND DUNE PHACELIA.

THE SOUTHERN NEW ENGLAND COASTAL PROGRAM (SNEP) WILL BE HIRING A HISPANIC ACCESS FOUNDATION INTERN TO SUPPORT PRIORITIES OF THE FIELD OFFICE. SNEP IS ONE OF 24 COASTAL PROGRAM OFFICES IN THE UNITED STATES, ESTABLISHED BY THE U.S. FISH   WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE) TO BUILD PARTNERSHIPS TO IDENTIFY, PROTECT AND RESTORE NATIONALLY SIGNIFICANT HABITAT FOR FISH, WILDLIFE AND PEOPLE. THE STAFF IN THE SNEP OFFICE PRIMARILY CONCENTRATE THEIR CONSERVATION EFFORTS IN COASTAL AREAS OF FOUR STATES WHERE THEY COMPLEMENT THE WORK OF OTHER PROGRAMS WITHIN THE SERVICE WHILE ALSO WORKING IN CLOSE PARTNERSHIP WITH CONSERVATION PARTNERS. THE WIDE VARIETY OF HABITATS, SPECIES, AND PARTNERS THAT ARE ADDRESSED IN THE SNEP OFFICE WILL PROVIDE A DIVERSITY OF OPPORTUNITIES FOR AN INTERN TO EXPLORE DIFFERENT ASPECTS OF THE CONSERVATION FIELD. WHILE THERE ARE SOME CORE PROJECTS THE INTERN WILL BE FOCUSING ON THAT SUPPORT THE PROVIDENCE URBAN WILDLIFE REFUGE PARTNERSHIP AND THE SCHOOLYARD HABITAT PROGRAM, WE LOOK FORWARD TO ACCOMMODATING THE SPECIFIC INTERESTS AND SKILLSET(S) OF THE CANDIDATE AND WELCOME THEIR ASSISTANCE ON ANY PROJECTS THAT INTEREST THEM.  THE INTERN WILL PRIMARILY FOCUS ON 1) COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND OUTREACH, 2) URBAN HABITAT RESTORATION, 3) ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION, AND 4) ASSISTING IN COORDINATING AND FACILITATING EVENTS ASSOCIATED WITH THE VAMOS A PESCAR  TAKE ME FISHING SERIES THROUGHOUT THE STATE. TASKS WILL INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO:  WORKING WITH K-12 PUBLIC SCHOOLS AND PARTNERS TO ASSIST WITH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE LEARNING INSIDE OUT INITIATIVE. ASSIST WITH IDENTIFYING AND BUILDING RELATIONSHIPS WITH COMMUNITY COLLABORATORS FOR THE NARDUCCI LEARNING CENTER SCHOOLYARD HABITAT CO-DESIGN PROJECT, INCLUDING PLANNING AND HOSTING COMMUNITY EVENTS, DEVELOPING AND EVALUATING SURVEYS, AND PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE IN PROJECT PLANNING AND DESIGN.   COORDINATING PRE-ARRANGED BILINGUAL FISHING EVENTS THROUGHOUT THE SUMMER, INCLUDING DURING LATINO CONSERVATION WEEK. THIS POSITION WILL ALSO HAVE OPPORTUNITIES TO SHADOW SERVICE STAFF FOR FIELD WORK ASSOCIATED WITH VARIOUS HABITAT RESTORATION AND WILDLIFE BIOLOGY PROJECTS. ADDITIONAL TASKS THAT MAY BE OFFERED BASED ON THE SPECIFIC INTERESTS AND SKILLS OF THE INTERN INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO: ASSISTING WITH SALT MARSH HABITAT AND BIRD SURVEYS IN CT AND NY CONDUCTING ACOUSTIC BAT SURVEYS AND ASSISTING WITH DATA ANALYSIS ASSISTING WITH THE TRANSPORT AND MONITORING OF NEW ENGLAND COTTONTAIL RABBITS PARTICIPATING IN SURVEYS OF THE FEDERALLY THREATENED AMERICAN BURYING BEETLE ON BLOCK ISLAND AND OR NANTUCKET

NEW JERSEY AUDUBON WILL CONDUCT POINT COUNT SURVEYS AT JBMDL LAKEHURST DURING THE 2023 BREEDING SEASON TO QUANTIFY ABUNDANCE AND OCCUPANCY BY GRASSLAND BIRD SPECIES, INCLUDING NJ-LISTED THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES SUCH AS GRASSHOPPER SPARROW (AMMODRAMUS SAVANNARUM) AND EASTERN MEADOWLARK (STURNELLA MAGNA ) IN AREAS THAT ARE MOWED TO MAINTAIN THE GRASS AT A HEIGHT OF 7-14 INCHES COMPARED TO AREAS WHERE THE GRASS IS NOT MOWED UNTIL THE CONCLUSION OF THE GROWING SEASON IN LATE SEPTEMBER. SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED WEEKLY FROM MAY 10 THROUGH JULY 28 (10 WEEKS). DATA WILL BE COLLECTED USING 0-3 AND 3-5 -MINUTE OBSERVATION PERIODS. BIRD DATA WILL INCLUDE ALL SPECIES SEEN HEARD WITHIN 100 METERS OF THE SURVEY POINT.AT THE CONCLUSION OF THE 2023 BREEDING SEASON, WE WILL UNDERTAKE DATA ANALYSIS ON THE 5 YEARS OF THE SURVEY USING DETECTION PROBABILITY MODELING AND APPROPRIATE STATISTICAL ANALYSIS TO LOOK AT DIFFERENCES BETWEEN THE TWO TREATMENT AREAS IN PROVIDING HABITAT FOR BY GRASSLAND BIRDS. WE WILL TABULATE AND SUMMARIZE THE DATA COLLECTED OVER THE FIVE YEARS OF THE STUDY, AND BECAUSE IMPERFECT DETECTION CAN BIAS SURVEY RESULTS, WE WILL USE DISTANCE SAMPLING AND MODEL DETECTION PROBABILITY TO CORRECT FOR THESE BIASES. WE WILL ADJUST THE DENSITIES WITHIN EACH POINT COUNT CIRCLE BASED ON THE RAW DATA USING THE FORMULA CORRECTED DENSITY  MEASURED DENSITY DETECTION PROBABILITY. WE WILL COMPARE BIRD DENSITY OF MOWED AND UN-MOWED POINTS USING REPEATED MEASURES PARAMETRIC STATISTICS AND PROVIDE A FINAL REPORT WITH THE RESULTS OF THE STUDY.THIS PROJECT CONTRIBUTES TO JOINT BASE MCGUIRE-DIX-LAKEHURST S GOAL TO PREVENT FLOCKING BIRDS FROM NESTING NEAR AIRFIELDS ON THE JOINT BASE. NESTING MIGRATORY BIRDS WILL BENEFIT THROUGH INFORMED DECISION MAKING BY JOINT BASE STAFF THAT BEST PROTECTS NESTING BIRDS WHILE ALLOWING FOR AIRFIELD OPERATIONS.

SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED FOR SECRETIVE MARSH BIRDS IN ALL ACCESSIBLE EMERGENT WETLANDS OF FORT DIX (PRIMARY SITE) AND LAKEHURST (SECONDARY SITE). SECRETIVE MARSH BIRDS ARE A GROUP OF CRYPTIC, WETLAND-DEPENDENT WATERBIRDS THAT BREED IN VEGETATIVE EMERGENT WETLANDS THROUGHOUT NORTH AMERICA (E.G., BITTERNS, RAILS, AND GALLINULES), MANY OF WHICH ARE SPECIES OF CONCERN, INCLUDING AMERICAN BITTERNS (BOTAURUS LENTIGINOSUS), LEAST BITTERNS (IXOBRYCHUS EXILIS), KING RAILS (RALLUS ELEGANS), AND PIED-BILLED GREBES (PODILYMBUS PODICEPS). NOT ALL WETLANDS ARE OCCUPIED BY, OR EVEN SUITABLE FOR, SECRETIVE MARSH BIRDS. THE CRYPTIC NATURE OF SECRETIVE MARSH BIRDS PAIRED WITH LIMITED ON-THE-GROUND FIELD SAMPLING FOR THESE BIRDS ON MILITARY SITES HAS RESULTED IN AN INCOMPLETE UNDERSTANDING OF WHICH INSTALLATIONS PROVIDE HABITAT FOR EACH SPECIES. FORT DIX IS RANKED AMONG THE TOP TEN MILITARY INSTALLATIONS FOR HABITAT SUITABILITY FOR FOUR SPECIES, PIED-BILLED GREBE, LEAST BITTERN, KING RAIL, AND COMMON GALLINULE (GALLINULA GALEATA). ROUTES AND POINTS WILL BE ESTABLISHED ALONG ROADS ADJACENT TO WETLAND HABITAT FOR FENCED AREAS THAT CANNOT BE ACCESSED, AND ALONG PATHS AND TRAILS FOR AREAS THAT ARE NOT FENCED OFF. AVIAN SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED AT EACH POINT APPROXIMATELY EVERY 2 WEEKS DURING THE BREEDING SEASON FROM MID-APRIL UNTIL MID-JUNE 2023, DURING THE SURVEY WINDOWS RECOMMENDED IN THE STANDARDIZED NORTH AMERICAN MARSH BIRD MONITORING PROTOCOL FOR NEW JERSEY. BECAUSE THE TARGET SPECIES ARE SELDOM OBSERVED AND VOCALIZE INFREQUENTLY, WE WILL USE BROADCAST CALLS TO ELICIT VOCALIZATIONS DURING SURVEYS. WE WILL DETERMINE AND REPORT ON THE NUMBER OF POINTS AND SITES WHERE EACH SPECIES WAS OBSERVED AND CALCULATE RELATIVE FREQUENCY OF OCCURRENCE FOR EACH SPECIES OBSERVED, INCLUDING THE (1) NUMBER OF POINT LOCATIONS A SPECIES WAS OBSERVED TOTAL NUMBER OF POINT LOCATIONS SURVEYED  AND (2) NUMBER OF SITES WHERE A SPECIES WAS OBSERVED  NUMBER OF SITES SURVEYED.  IDENTIFICATION AND WISE MANAGEMENT OF WETLANDS THAT PROVIDE HABITAT FOR THESE SPECIES IS VITAL TO ENSURING SECRETIVE MARSH BIRD PERSISTENCE AND IS LEGALLY MANDATED ON FEDERAL LANDS WITHIN THE U.S. FOR SPECIES PROTECTED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. SECRETIVE MARSH BIRDS WILL BENEFIT THROUGH INFORMED DECISION MAKING BY JOINT BASE STAFF THAT INTEGRATES REGIONAL ECOSYSTEM MANAGEMENT, MILITARY READINESS, RANGE SUSTAINMENT, AND CONSERVATION GOALS.

THE SAN JUAN ISLANDS CONSERVATION DISTRICT SEEKS FUNDING TO CONTINUE EELGRASS MEADOW RESTORATION EFFORTS AT BELL POINT IN WESTCOTT BAY AND BEGIN RESTORATION AT MULTIPLE OTHER SITES IN THE SAN JUAN ISLANDS.RAPID DISAPPEARANCE OF EELGRASS IN THE SAN JUAN S HAS BEEN WELL-DOCUMENTED AT SPECIFIC AND WIDESPREAD SITES SINCE THE EARLY 2000S (WA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES PUGET SOUND SEAGRASS MONITORING REPORT NEARSHORE HABITAT PROGRAM (CHRISTIAEN B. ET AL 2017)). THIS LOSS IS NOT FULLY UNDERSTOOD BUT CARRIES WITH IT MANY SEVERE ENVIRONMENTAL, ECONOMIC AND CULTURAL IMPACTS. IN THE CONTEXT OF SALMON RECOVERY ALONE, HEALTHY EELGRASS IS ONE OF THE MOST CRITICAL COMPONENTS FOR LONG TERM CHINOOK SALMON SURVIVAL BECAUSE IT HOSTS THE EGGS OF FORAGE FISH THAT SALMON PREY ON AND PROVIDES SAFE HARBOR FOR THE JUVENILE SALMON THEMSELVES.AT THIS TIME, LIMITED RESTORATION EFFORTS HAVE BEEN ATTEMPTED BY DNR OR OTHER AGENCIES. RESTORATION EFFORTS BY DNR HAVE FOCUSED ON TRANSPLANTING ADULT PLANTS AND HAVE NOT PROVEN SUCCESSFUL, WITH LOW OR NO PLANT SURVIVAL OBSERVED.THE DIRECT SEEDING EFFORTS DESCRIBED HERE, UNDERTAKEN BY SAN JUAN ISLANDS CONSERVATION DISTRICT IN PARTNERSHIP WITH UW FRIDAY HARBOR LABS AND DNR, ARE SHOWING SIGNS OF SUCCESS. SEEDING IS GAINING GLOBAL SUPPORT AS A COST-EFFECTIVE METHOD THAT DESERVES TO BE STUDIED, IMPROVED, AND APPLIED BROADLY THROUGHOUT THE SALISH SEA AND PUGET SOUND.IN 2023-2025, OUR PROJECT TEAM IS SEEKING FUNDING TO CONTINUE WORK COMPLETED BETWEEN 2019-2022. OUR WORK HAS FOCUSED ON SEED COLLECTION, STORAGE, AND PLANTING TECHNIQUES. OVER THE PAST THREE YEARS OUR TEAM HAS:- INCREASED SEED HARVEST VOLUMES FROM ROUGHLY 5,000 TO 35,000 SEEDS ANNUALLY,- INCREASED SEED STORAGE CAPACITY AND IMPROVED INFRASTRUCTURE COMMENSURATE WITH SEED VOLUMES,- TESTED SEVERAL DIRECT SEEDING TECHNIQUESSPECIFIC OBJECTIVES IN THE NEXT 2-3 YEARS INCLUDE:1. INCREASE SEED COLLECTION VOLUME AND STORAGE CAPACITY FROM  50,000 TO  500,000 SEEDS.2. CONTINUE REPEATED SEED PLANTING AND MONITORING IN WESTCOTT BAY AND EXPORT APPROPRIATE SEEDING TECHNIQUES TO 3-4 ADDITIONAL SITES IN SAN JUAN COUNTY.3. INCREASE COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT OPPORTUNITIES FOR LOCAL RESIDENTS AND LANDOWNERS TO CONTRIBUTE TO PROGRAM SUCCESS, ESPECIALLY WATERFRONT LANDOWNERS.4. MAINTAIN A ROBUST SEED BANK, PROGRESS REPORT AND PROGRAM MANUAL TO SUPPORT BROADER EELGRASS SEEDING EFFORTS ALONG THE WASHINGTON COAST.5. PROVIDE SEEDS FROM CENTRAL SEED BANK TO SUPPORT RESTORATION EFFORTS UNDERTAKEN BY LANDOWNERS THROUGHOUT THE REGION.

NORTHEAST MICHIGAN CONTAINS MANY MILES OF LAKE HURON SHORELINE HABITATS AND ISLANDS THAT SUPPORT GLOBALLY SIGNIFICANT SPECIES ASSEMBLAGES. THE DISRUPTION OF NATURAL PROCESSES FROM POLLUTION, DEVELOPMENT, CLIMATE CHANGE AND INVASIVE SPECIES HAS CAUSED THE EXTIRPATION AND DECLINE OF MANY SPECIES IN THE REGION. WHILE MANY OF THE LAKE HURON ISLANDS HAVE BEEN SPARED THE PRESSURE OF HUMAN DISTURBANCE, THEY ARE ESPECIALLY VULNERABLE TO THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND INVASIVE SPECIES. HURON PINES AND OUR PARTNERS, USFWS PERSONNEL, MICHIGAN NATURAL FEATURES INVENTORY, AND LOCAL MUNICIPALITIES, HAVE PRIORITIZED 10 ISLANDS OF CONSERVATION SIGNIFICANCE IN LAKE HURON TO RECEIVE COMPREHENSIVE RESTORATION EFFORTS THAT WILL BENEFIT AND SUSTAIN LOCAL BIODIVERSITY AND INFORM CONSERVATION STRATEGIES FOR MICHIGAN S GREAT LAKES ISLANDS. THESE ACTIVITIES INCLUDE EXTENSIVE SURVEYS TO REPLACE INCOMPLETE OR OUTDATED ISLAND INVENTORIES, INVASIVE SPECIES TREATMENTS, POPULATION MONITORING AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT FOR FEDERALLY ENDANGERED PIPING PLOVER, POPULATION MONITORING AND AUGMENTATION FOR FEDERALLY THREATENED PITCHER S THISTLE, AND PRESCRIBED FIRE. THROUGH THIS COLLABORATIVE, LANDSCAPE-LEVEL PROJECT, MANY SPECIES THAT RELY ON GLOBALLY SIGNIFICANT SHORELINE HABITATS WILL BENEFIT SIMULTANEOUSLY.

ADDITIONALLY, DU SERVICES WILL INCLUDE SUBRECIPIENT AWARDS WITH THIRD PARTY CONSULTANTS TO COMPLETE PERMITTING WITH USACE AND TEXAS GLO. NESIKA PRESERVE RESTORATION ASSESSMENTTHE NESIKA PRESERVE IS ABOUT 7 MILES NORTH OF GOLD BEACH, OR AND IS APPROXIMATELY 100 ACRES IN SIZE. IT COMPRISES ONE 40-ACRE PROPERTY OWNED BY THE WILD RIVERS LAND TRUST AND THREE PRIVATELY HELD PROPERTIES WITH CONSERVATIONEASEMENTS PLACED ON THEM TO PROTECT NATURAL AREAS. TWO OF THE PRIVATELY HELD PROPERTIES WITH EASEMENTS ON THEM HAVE OCEANFRONT COASTAL BLUFFS ON THEM, AND WRLT IS EXPLORING THE IDEA OF DOING RESTORATION WORK IN THESE AREAS TO RESTORE A MORE NATURAL CONDITION ON THESE COASTAL HEADLANDS.THE CURRENT CONDITION OF THE COASTAL BLUFFS IS DIFFERENT BETWEEN THE TWO PROPERTIES. AT THE NORTHERN PROPERTY, THE BLUFF IS FAIRLY OPEN ON THE SOUTH END AND IS MOSTLY COMPRISED OF LOW-LYING NATIVE VEGETATION, ALTHOUGH THERE ARE SPOTS OF INVASIVE ICE PLANT THAT THE LANDOWNERS AND WRLT HAVE BEEN WORKING ON REMOVING FROM THE PROPERTY. TO THE NORTH, SHORE PINE HAS ENCROACHED ON FORMALLY OPEN SANDY AREAS AND THERE IS A MIX OF NATIVE SHRUBS INTERMIXED WITH THE PINES. THE FAMILY THAT OWNS THE PROPERTY HAS TOLD US THAT THIS AREA WAS ALL OPEN AND FLAT 50 YEARS AGO. THE BLUFFS ON THE SOUTHERN PROPERTY ARE MOSTLY GROWN IN BY DENSE SHRUBS AND SMALL SHORE PINES. FOR THE MOST PART THIS VEGETATION IS AROUND 4-6 FEET IN HEIGHT AND SUNLIGHT DOES NOT PENETRATE TO THE GROUND IN THIS AREA. THE FORMER CONDITION OF THIS AREA WAS OPEN, SIMILAR TO THE SOUTHERN BLUFF AREA ON THE NORTHERN PROPERTY. BOTH LANDOWNERS ARE OPEN TO THE IDEA OF RESTORATION WORK HAPPENING ON THEIR PROPERTY, BUT WOULD LIKE TO SEE A PLAN FOR SPECIFIC ACTIONS TAKING INTO ACCOUNT ANY CONCERNS THEY HAVE. FOR EXAMPLE, THE LANDOWNERS ON THE SOUTHERN PROPERTY HAVE SOME AREAS THEY WOULD LIKE TO STAY THE WAY THEY ARE CURRENTLY. WE DISCUSSED THE IDEA OF CREATING A RESTORATION PLAN THAT WOULD LAY OUT SOME SPECIFIC ACTIONS AND EXPLORE THE FEASIBILITY OF DIFFERENT APPROACHES THAT WE COULD TAKE BACK TO THE LANDOWNERS. IT WOULD ALSO HELP US ESTABLISH A TIMELINE FOR COMPLETION.

IN 2020, THE COASTAL PRAIRIE RESTORATION AT CROOK POINT, A HEADLAND ON THE SOUTHERN OREGON COAST MANAGED AS PART OF THE OREGON ISLANDS NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE WAS INITIATED. TO DATE, OVER 20 ACRES HAVE BEEN TREATED BY REDUCING THE COVER OF INVASIVE SPECIES FOLLOWED BY PLANTING AND SEEDING OF NATIVE PRAIRIE PLANTS. THERE IS A NEED TO DEVELOP A MONITORING PROTOCOL TO GAUGE RESTORATION EFFICACY AND INFORM ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT. THE UNDERSTORY INITIATIVE WILL CREATE AND TEST A RAPID HABITAT ASSESSMENT METHOD FOR CROOK POINT WITH THE GOAL OF GAINING INSIGHT INTO RESTORATION PROJECT EFFECTIVENESS AND INFORMING FUTURE LAND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES ON THE SITE.

THOMPSON CREEK IS A TRIBUTARY TO THE SKAGIT RIVER BETWEEN CONCRETE AND ROCKPORT NEAR HIGHWAY SR20. A BARRIER ( 994221) CURRENTLY BLOCKS FISH PASSAGE TO 0.75 MILES OF HABITAT UPSTREAM. THIS SUMMER WSDOT WILL BE CORRECTING A STATE OWNED BARRIER CULVERT LOCATED LESS THAN 500 FEET UPSTREAM. SFEG IS SEEKING FUNDS TO REMOVE THIS PRIVATE BARRIER CULVERT AND REPLACE IT WITH AN ATV LAWN MOWER CROSSING. THIS PROJECT ALSO BUILDS ON A BARRIER REMOVAL DOWNSTREAM ON SAUK STORE ROAD THAT SKAGIT COUNTY COMPLETED IN 2012. IN ADDITION TO PROVIDING FISH PASSAGE TO CHINOOK, COHO, CHUM, PINK AND STEELHEAD, REMOVING THE BARRIER CULVERTS ON THOMPSON CREEK AND INSTALLING AN ATV BRIDGE WILL ALSO PERMANENTLY STOP THE CREEK FROM FLOWING OVER THE ROAD AND KEEP FOOT AND ATV TRAFFIC OUT OF THE CREEK. IT WILL ALSO ALLOW LARGE WOODY DEBRIS MOVEMENT FROM THE MATURE RIPARIAN FOREST DOWNSTREAM. THOMPSON CREEK IS CURRENTLY 100  BLOCKED TO FISH ACCESS ACCORDING TO WDFW CRITERIA BY THIS BARRIER AND IS LISTED AS A HABITAT FOR CHINOOK, COHO, CHUM, STEELHEAD, AND PINK SALMON ON WDFW S SALMONSCAPE. THOMPSON CREEK IS WELL FORESTED WITH A HEALTHY, MATURE, RIPARIAN BUFFER CONSISTING OF CONIFERS AND SHRUBS. THE CHANNEL HAS HIGH HABITAT COMPLEXITY AND SINUOSITY WITH ABUNDANT LARGE WOODY DEBRIS AND GRAVEL FOR SPAWNING. THE CURRENT CULVERTS ARE VERY DISRUPTIVE TO NORMAL SEDIMENT, WOOD AND WATER FLOW. IN WINTER WATER IS FREQUENTLY FORCED TO OVERTOP THE ROAD. REPLACING THIS CROSSING WITH A SMALL ATV BRIDGE WOULD RESTORE FISH ACCESS AND NATURAL PROCESSES. THE THOMPSON CREEK PROJECT WAS IDENTIFIED DUE TO WSDOT DOING A BARRIER REMOVAL PROJECT UPSTREAM OF THIS SITE. THIS PROJECT WILL REMOVE A SMALL PRIVATE BARRIER AND ENSURE THAT THE PUBLIC MONEY SPENT FIXING THE UPSTREAM BARRIER ACTUALLY BENEFITS SALMON. ON THOMPSON CREEK THE BARRIER CULVERT CAUSES THE STREAM TO FLOW OVER THE ROAD AND MEANDER UNNATURALLY IN THE FOREST AROUND THE CROSSING, LEADING TO UNNATURAL EROSION AND DISTRIBUTION OF GRAVEL ROAD FILL. REMOVING THE BARRIER WILL REMOVE THIS UNNATURAL CHANNEL DISRUPTION AND IMPROVE WATER QUALITY IN DOWNSTREAM REACHES. SEVERAL FORESTED WETLAND COMPLEXES ARE MAPPED DOWNSTREAM 0.4 MILES DOWNSTREAM ASSOCIATED WITH THE SKAGIT RIVER.

THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS BRINGING BACK HEALTHY SALMON, BULLTROUT AND STEELHEAD POPULATION TO HOOD CANAL'S WATERSHEDS  TOWARDS A LARGER GOAL OF SELF-SUSTAINING RUNS. THESE GOALS ARE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH HABITAT RESTORATION,  RESEARCH, MONITORING, ADMINISTRATION AND EDUCATION OF THE PUBLIC ABOUT THE IMPORTANCE OF WILD SALMON, BULLTROUT  AND STEELHEAD IN OUR ECOSYSTEMS. THIS PROJECT IS ONGOING.  HCSEG'S (HOOD CANAL SALMON ENHANCEMENT GROUP) ACTIVITIES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO: PERPETUATING AND ENHANCING THE GENETIC DIVERSITY AND STOCKS  OF WILD SALMON, BULLTROUT AND STEELHEAD IN HCANAL THROUGH PROTECTION AND RESTORATION OF THESE SPECIES,  STEWARDSHIP AND RESEARCH FOR WATERSHED AND MARINE ECOSYSTEMS, HABITAT RESTORATION, COMMUNITY EDUCATION AND  OUTREACH, AND ANY OTHER MEANS APPROPRIATE. HCSEG IS A 501-3 NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATION.  HCSEG COVERS AN EXTENSIVE REGION WITHIN THE PUGET SOUND. AREAS OF OPERATION THROUGHOUT HOOD CANAL'S WATERSHEDS  ARE LISTED WITH PROJECT DESCRIPTION/TITLE IN HCSEG'S WORK PLAN/STATEMENT OF WORK/PROGRAM/BUDGET NARRATIVE.  USFWS'S FUNDING SUPPORTS OUR OPERATIONS MAINLY THROUGH PERSONNEL COSTS BY MONTHLY STAFF BILLINGS AND GENERAL  OPERATING EXPENSES. THIS CRITICAL FUNDING WHILE SUPPORTING MOSTLY PERSONNEL COSTS ALLOWS OUR GROUP TO HAVE AN  EXTENSIVE REACH IN OUR WATERSHED AND THUS SUPPORTS ALL OUR OPERATIONS NOTED IN PROJECT LIST IN HCSEG'S WORKPLAN.

CHAMAECRISTA GLANDULOSA VAR  MIRABILIS IS AN ENDANGERED SPECIES OF LEGUME ENDEMIC OF PUERTO RICO  THE POPULATION C  GLANDULOSA VAR  MIRABILIS IS ISOLATED IN TWO LOCATIONS IN THE TORTUGUERO LAGOON NATURE RESERVE  TLNR  AT NORTH COAST OF PUERTO RICO  THIS ECOSYSTEM COVERS 75 SQUARE KILOMETERS, INCLUDING THE WATERSHED THAT EXTENDS TO THE KARSTIC PROTECTED ZONE BETWEEN THE VEGA BAJA AND MANAT MUNICIPALITIES  THE TLNR SOIL IS MAINLY COMPOSED OF SILICA SANDS, DEPOSITS THAT ARE UNIQUE IN PUERTO RICO, AND THE PLANTS FOUND IN THEM ARE ADAPTED TO THIS TYPE OF SUBSTRATE  THE TLNR HAS ONE OF THE MOST SIGNIFICANT FRESHWATER BODIES IN NORTHERN PUERTO RICO AND IS AN IMPORTANT HABITAT FOR OTHER ENDANGERED SPECIES SUCH AS OTTOSCHULZIA RHODOXYLON, SCHOEPFIA ARENARIA AND CHILABOTHRUS INORNATUS, AS WELL AS SEVERAL SPECIES OF RARE ALLOTETRAPLOID HYBRID FERNS  E G , POLYPODIUM AUREUM  AND GRASSES  E G , CYPERUS PULGUERENSIS AND PANICUM STEVENSIANUM  CHAMAECRISTA GLANDULOSA VAR  MIRABILIS HAS BEEN LISTED AS ENDANGERED BY FEDERAL AND LOCAL AUTHORITIES SINCE 1990, AND CONTINUES THREATENED BY PHYSICAL DAMAGE CAUSED BY HUMAN TRAMPLING, ATVS, HORSES, HUMAN INDUCED FIRES, COMPETITION FROM THE EXOTIC GRASS AND THE PARASITIC PLANT  E G , CASSYTHA FILIFORMIS , AS WELL AS CLIMATE CHANGE EFFECTS CAN AFFECT INTO THE FUTURE  MORE RECENTLY, THE HABITAT AND LANDSCAPE AREA HAS BEEN AFFECTED BY SEVERAL UNREGULATED ACTIVITIES SUCH AS THE CREATION OF CLANDESTINE TRAILS, LEADING TO ADDITIONAL HABITAT MODIFICATION AND FRAGMENTATION  THESE HAS RESULTED IN HABITAT INTRUSION BY EXOTIC PLANT SPECIES  E G , MEGATHYRSUS MAXIMUS , AND THE HABITAT BEEN IMPACTED BY A YEARLY REGIME OF HUMA INDUCED FIRES THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO ADDRESS THE THREATS TO THE RECOVERY AND CONSERVATION OF THE SPECIES BY DEVELOPING AND VALIDATING A HABITAT MODEL INCLUDING THE DORADO AREA AND OTHER ADJACENT PRIVATE LANDS ON THE NORTH COAST, USE THE HABITAT MODEL TO INFORM THE SELECTION OF REINTRODUCTION SITES FOR THE SPECIES, CONDUCT A PILOT REINTRODUCTION PROJECT IN THE AREAS IDENTIFIED AS POTENTIAL FOR REINTRODUCTION, DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A VEGETATION MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR THE CONTROL OF INVASIVE SPECIES TO REDUCE HUMAN INDUCE FIRE IN THE PROXIMITY OF KNOWN POPULATION OF C  GLANDULOSA VAR  MIRABILIS, ENHANCE THE HABITAT THROUGH THE PROPAGATION OF NATIVE SHRUBS ASSOCIATED WITH C  GLANDULOSA VAR  MIRABILIS HABITAT, INCREASE THE ABUNDANCE OF POLLINATORS AND STRENGTHEN NATIVE BEE COMMUNITIES SUCH AS XYLOCOPA MORDAX WITHIN THE RESERVE USING BEE HOTELS, AND CONDUCT OUTREACH ACTIVITIES  E G , ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION AND COMMUNITY MEETINGS   THEREFORE, THE FOCUS OF THE PROJECT IS TO USE HABITAT MODELING TO PREDICT SUITABLE SITES FOR THE FUTURE REINTRODUCTION AND ESTABLISHMENT OF NEW POPULATIONS OF C  GLANDULOSA VAR  MIRABILIS, AND THE IMPLEMENTATION OF HABITAT REMEDIATION ACTIONS AND RECOMMENDATION SUCH AS MANAGEMENT PLAN TO REDUCE EXISTING THREATS JEOPARDIZING THE SPECIES AND SUPPORTING CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY OF C  GLANDULOSA VAR  MIRABILIS IN THE FUTURE

THIS AGREEMENT WITH OCCIDENTAL ARTS AND ECOLOGY CENTER  OAEC  IS AIMED AT DEMONSTRATING PROCESS BASED RESTORATION APPLICATIONS AND TECHNIQUES IN THE COASTAL STREAMS OF MARIN COUNTY  THESE APPROACHES ARE LOW COST AND HAVE SIGNIFICANT POTENTIAL TO RESTORE AQUATIC HABITAT FOR VARIOUS SPECIES INCLUDING SENSITIVE AMPHIBIANS AND ANADROMOUS FISH IN THIS COASTAL REGION  DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS IN THREE MARIN COUNTY STREAMS WILL INVOLVE WORKING WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, STATE PARKS, AND THE MARIN COUNTY RCD AND AIMED AT THE RESTORATION OF 0 25 MILES OF A TRIBUTARY STREAM TO STEMPLE CREEK, LIVESTOCK FENCING AND PROJECT PLANNING FOR 2 MILES OF WALKER CREEK AND PLANNING AND DESIGN FOR 1 MILE OF DEVILS GULCH  THESE STREAMS ARE COASTAL TRIBUTARIES TO SALTWATER MARSH AND COASTAL WETLANDS IN TOMALES BAY AND ESTERO SAN ANTONIO  THE THREE PROJECT SITES MAY ALSO PROVIDE HABITAT FOR REINTRODUCTION OF BEAVER CURRENTLY UNDER CONSIDERATION BY THE MARIN RCD, NATIONAL MARINE FISHERIES SERVICE, AND CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE  STEMPLE CREEK SPRING TRIBUTARY IS LOCATED ON A LIVESTOCK RANCH IN MARIN COUNTY  THIS AREA PROVIDES IMPORTANT HABITAT FOR RED LEGGED FROG  THE STREAM SPRING IS CURRENTLY IN A GULLEY WITH A NARROW BAND OF RIPARIAN VEGETATION AND PROVIDES MINIMAL HABITAT FOR AMPHIBIANS AND MIGRATORY BIRDS  THE GULLEY PROVIDES ONLY SHALLOW WATER HABITAT, IT DRAINS AREA WETLANDS AND REDUCES OVERALL RIPARIAN VEGETATION PRODUCTION AND HABITAT  WALKER CREEK IS IMPORTANT HABITAT FOR SPAWNING COHO AND STEELHEAD AND A MAJOR HABITAT LIMITING FACTOR FOR ANADROMOUS FISH IN THIS SYSTEM IS FINE SEDIMENT POLLUTION FROM LIVESTOCK  CONTROLLING LIVESTOCK ACCESS TO TRIBUTARY STREAM AREAS COULD SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCE FINE SEDIMENT POLLUTION IN THIS SYSTEM  ADDITIONALLY THIS STREAM LACKS HABITAT COMPLEXITY THAT COULD BE PROVIDED THROUGH WOOD ADDITION  DEVILS GULCH IS A MAJOR SPAWNING TRIBUTARY FOR COHO SALMON  MOST OF THIS STREAM IS OWNED BY THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA AT SAMUEL P TAYLOR PARK  WHILE THE STREAM HAS SIGNIFICANT RIPARIAN FOREST THE CHANNEL IS SIMPLIFIED OR  STRUCTURALLY STARVED  WITH VERY LITTLE INSTREAM WOOD OR CHANNEL HABITAT COMPLEXITY  PLACEMENT OF WOOD STRUCTURE BY HAND IN THIS SYSTEM WILL IMPROVE THE HABITAT INCLUDING POOL DEVELOPMENT, FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY, AND SPAWNING GRAVEL WITHOUT CAUSING DISTURBANCE IN THIS SYSTEM FROM THE USE OF HEAVY MACHINERY

WE SEEK TO INCREASE THE RESILIENCE OF COASTAL COMMUNITIES AND HABITATS TO EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS  AND OTHER EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE IN 8 MUNICIPALITIES OF THE NORTH COAST OF PUERTO RICO  WE WILL  IMPLEMENT INNOVATIVE NATURE BASED ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION TECHNIQUES IN 34 DAMAGED SITES AND WILL  COMPLEMENT THE ON THE GROUND WORK WITH AN ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION COMPONENT  THIS WILL  ENGAGE LOCAL COMMUNITIES AND STAKEHOLDERS TO ACTION AND WILL INCLUDE A PLAN TO TRANSFER LESSONS  LEARNED TO OTHER COMMUNITIES ON THE ISLAND  THE RESULTS AND RECOMMENDATIONS THAT WILL RESULT FROM  THE PROJECT WILL ALSO BE INTEGRATED INTO GOVERNMENT PLANS   THE GOALS ARE TO  1  STRENGTHEN COASTAL RESILIENCE BY MITIGATING NATURAL HAZARDS WITH NATURE BASED  TECHNIQUES, 2  ACHIEVE CONSERVATION OF ECOSYSTEMS AND INCREASE BIODIVERSITY THROUGH THE ECOLOGICAL  RESTORATION, 3  INFORM COMMUNITIES OF OUR WORK AND 4  EDUCATE AND ENGAGE THE POPULATION BY USING  ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION AND CITIZEN SCIENCE MONITORING   THE FRAGILE COASTAL DUNES OF THE NORTH COAST OF PUERTO RICO WERE SEVERELY DEGRADED AND DESTROYED  DURING THE HURRICANE SEASON OF 2017, LEAVING COASTAL COMMUNITIES AND WILDLIFE HABITATS VULNERABLE  TO THE EFFECTS OF STORMS AND OTHER EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE   VIDA MARINA IS CURRENTLY WORKING ON THE SUCCESSFUL ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION OF 53 HIGH PRIORITY DUNE  SITES ALONG THE NORTH COAST OF THE ISLAND BUT NEED TO RESTORE ADDITIONAL ONES  THIS PROJECT FOCUSES ON  THE ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION OF AN ADDITIONAL 34 DEGRADED SITES  24 KM OF COASTLINE  THAT WHEN RESTORED  WILL OFFER SIGNIFICANT PROTECTION TO COASTAL COMMUNITIES AND WILDLIFE   STUDENTS, COMMUNITY VOLUNTEERS AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS WILL BE INSTALLING WOODEN BOARDWALKS,  SIGNAGE, SAND TRAPPING BIOMIMICRY MATRICES AND PLANTING VEGETATION TO STABILIZE THE ACCUMULATED  SAND  THE PROJECT INVOLVES MAPPING AND MONITORING WITH UAV AND INCLUDES AN ENVIRONMENTAL  EDUCATION COMPONENT THAT WILL TRAIN COMMUNITY MEMBERS, K 12 TEACHERS AND UNIVERSITY STUDENTS  TO BE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION RESOURCES AND CITIZEN SCIENTISTS   THIS WILL INCREASE COMMUNITY  BUY IN , STEWARDSHIP AND GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ON THE IMPORTANCE OF  PROTECTING DUNES AND THE WILDLIFE INHABITING THEM  RESTORING THESE ADDITIONAL SITES WILL INCREASE  THE RESILIENCE OF COMMUNITIES AND WILDLIFE HABITATS SIGNIFICANTLY BY PROTECTING THEM FROM  FUTURE HURRICANES AND OTHER EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE

THE MAN MADE MAINLAND BEACH OF GULFPORT, MISSISSIPPI IS HOME TO TWO HISTORICAL LEAST TERNSANCTUARIES WHICH HAVE BEEN DESIGNATED AS AN AUDUBON IMPORTANT BIRD AREA  IBA , WHICH IS AGLOBALLY RECOGNIZED DESIGNATION  THIS IBA HOLDS A SIGNIFICANT POPULATION OF BREEDING LEASTTERNS, A SPECIES WHICH HAS DECLINED ACROSS ITS RANGE DUE TO HABITAT LOSS AND DEGRADATION  THEHABITAT WITHIN THIS IBA HAS DEGRADED RECENTLY DUE TO LONG TERM BEACH EROSION AND RECENT HURRICANES THAT HAVE SCOURED AWAY THE DUNE PLANTINGS, DESTROYED THE WOODEN FENCING, AND WASHED AWAY THE LARGE INFORMATIONAL SIGNS  THE NUMBERS OF BREEDING TERNS USING THIS IBA HAVEDECLINED OVER THE PAST FIVE YEARS, AND AVIAN PREDATORS HAVE BEEN DOCUMENTED PREYING UPON LEASTTERN EGGS AND OCCASIONALLY RESULTING IN EXTENSIVE LOSS OF PRODUCTIVITY WE PROPOSE TO RESTORETHESE SANCTUARIES BY  1  RE ESTABLISHING DUNE SYSTEMS WITHIN THESE SANCTUARIES BY PLANTING DUNEVEGETATION AND USING INFORMATIONAL SIGNS AND ROPE TO PROTECT THE DUNE AREAS FROM TRAMPLING ANDRAKING  2  NEGOTIATE WITH HARRISON COUNTY SAND BEACH AUTHORITY TO REDUCE OR ELIMINATE BEACHRAKING YEAR ROUND WITHIN THESE SANCTUARIES IN ORDER TO REDUCE BEACH EROSION AND FLOODING RATES AND 3  SET UP PLOTS OF SHELL HASH TO IMPROVE NEST AND CHICK CAMOUFLAGE TO REDUCE LOSSES TO AVIANPREDATORS  THE DUNE PLANTS WILL REDUCE BEACH EROSION RATES, INCREASE BEACH ELEVATION, AND PROVIDESHELTER FOR YOUNG CHICKS, ALL OF WHICH WILL IMPROVE LEAST TERN BREEDING PRODUCTIVITY  ELIMINATIONOF BEACH RAKING WITHIN THIS AREA WILL ALSO REDUCE BEACH EROSION RATES AND REDUCE SUBSURFACE SANDCOMPACTION, WHICH EXACERBATES LOCALIZED FLOODING ISSUES DURING HEAVY RAINS AND LEADS TO NESTLOSS  THE SHELL HASH IS EXPECTED TO REDUCE NEST AND CHICK LOSS TO AVIAN PREDATORS, AND WILL BEPLACED IN AN EXPERIMENTAL MANNER THAT PERMITS COLLECTION OF NEST AND CHICK SURVIVAL DATA TO TESTTHIS HYPOTHESIS  THESE RESTORATION ACTIONS WILL BE TIMELY, COINCIDING WITH A COUNTY WIDE MAINLANDBEACH RENOURISHMENT PROJECT SET TO BEGIN IN LATE 2023, WHICH WILL WIDEN THE EXISTING BEACHES FURTHERMORE, IT WILL BE IMPORTANT TO RESTORE THE IMAGE OF THIS AREA AS A TERN SANCTUARY, GIVEN THERECENT SALE OF THE GREAT SOUTHERN GOLF COURSE ACROSS THE HIGHWAY FROM THIS IBS AND PLANS TOCOVERT THIS AREA TO A RESIDENTIAL SUBDIVISION

SALT MARSH RESTORATION IS BECOMING A LARGER FOCUS OF THE RESTORATION COMMUNITY IN THE MID ATLANTIC  ONE SUCH RESTORATION APPROACH IS TO USE LOW TECH, LOW COST, LOW DISTURBANCE TECHNIQUES TO SET THE MARSH ON A SELF HEALING TRAJECTORY  THESE TECHNIQUES INCLUDE THE CREATION OF RUNNELS TO ALLOW WATER TRAPPED ON THE MARSH TO MOVE FREELY WITH THE TIDES AS WELL AS REMEDIATION OF DITCHES IN EXTENSIVELY GRID DITCHED MARSHES TO HELP DECREASE THE CHANNEL DENSITY TO PROMOTE A MORE NATURAL HYDROLOGIC FUNCTION  WHILE THESE TECHNIQUES HAVE BEEN SHOWN TO BE SUCCESSFUL IN TERMS OF IMPROVEMENTS TO HYDROLOGY, ELEVATION, AND VEGETATION, LITTLE IS KNOWN HOW THE NEKTON COMMUNITY RESPONDS TO THESE TECHNIQUES  MARSHES PLAY AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN THE LIFE CYCLE FOR MANY AQUATIC SPECIES, MANY OF WHICH ARE IMPORTANT FISHERIES SPECIES  UNDERSTANDING HOW THESE SPECIES ARE INFLUENCED BY THESE TECHNIQUES WILL NOT ONLY INCREASE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE ECOLOGICAL RESPONSE TO RESTORATION, BUT WILL ALSO HELP ADDRESS CONCERNS FROM REGULATORY AGENCIES SUCH AS THE NATIONAL MARINE FISHERIES SERVICE WE INTEND TO INVESTIGATE HOW THESE RESTORATION TECHNIQUES AFFECT THE ABILITY OF NEKTON TO ACCESS DIFFERENT PORTIONS OF THE MARSH  TO DO THIS, WE WILL BE DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING AN APPROACH TO QUANTIFY THE CHANGES IN NEKTON COMMUNITY AND ABUNDANCE BY LOOKING AT ASSEMBLAGES BEFORE AND AFTER IMPLEMENTATION OF FUTURE RESTORATION PROJECTS  THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT PERTAINS TO DEVELOPING A PROTOCOL FOR ASSESSING THE NEKTON COMMUNITY, PARTLY IMPLEMENTING THAT PROTOCOL, AND ANALYZING DATA AND NOT THE RESTORATION ITSELF  BECAUSE ONE OF THE MAIN OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ESTABLISH A MONITORING PROTOCOL TO FIND THE MOST INFORMATIVE METHOD OF CAPTURING ANY SIGNIFICANT CHANGES IN THE NEKTON COMMUNITY IN RESPONSE TO THE THESE TECHNIQUES, THE SPECIFIC METHODS, TIMING, AND FREQUENCY HAVE NOT YET BEEN DETERMINED  HOWEVER, THE PROTOCOL WILL LIKELY INVOLVE SAMPLING APPROXIMATELY TWICE A MONTH THROUGH THE MONTHS OF MAY AND OCTOBER AT TO BE DETERMINED SALT MARSH SITES THROUGHOUT THE INLAND BAYS USING AN ARRAY OF MINNOW TRAPS, THROW TRAPS, AND OR DITCH NETS  WE ANTICIPATE THIS EFFORT TO EXTEND THROUGH DECEMBER OF 2026 WITH EACH SITE BEING SAMPLED FOR AT LEAST TWO YEARS DURING THAT TIME

THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON ESTABLISHING LONG TERM MONITORING OF KNOWN FLORIDA PERFORATE CLADONIA  CLADONIA PERFORATA  POPULATIONS, AS WELL AS CONDUCTING SURVEYS FOR NEW POPULATIONS IN AREAS WITH SUITABLE HABITAT  FLORIDA PERFORATE CLADONIA IS A FEDERALLY ENDANGERED SPECIES OF TERRESTRIAL LICHEN THAT ONLY OCCURS IN COASTAL AND INLAND SCRUB HABITATS IN FOUR REGIONS OF FLORIDA  OKALOOSA COUNTY IN THE PANHANDLE, THE ATLANTIC COAST RIDGE ON THE EAST COAST, THE LAKE WALES RIDGE IN THE CENTRAL PENINSULA, AND MANATEE COUNTY IN SOUTHWEST FLORIDA  CURRENTLY, MOST POPULATIONS OF THIS SPECIES ARE NOT CLOSELY MONITORED OR REGULARLY REVISITED TO ALLOW FOR A DETERMINATION OF THEIR STATUS AND TRENDS OVER TIME  BY ESTABLISHING RESEARCH PLOTS WITHIN THESE POPULATIONS, BOTANISTS WILL GAIN A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE STATUS, TRENDS, THREATS, AND NEEDS OF THE LICHEN POPULATIONS  ADDITIONALLY, SEARCHES FOR UNDOCUMENTED POPULATIONS TARGETED IN AREAS WITH THE CORRECT HABITAT TYPE FOR THIS SPECIES WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION ON THE TRUE DISTRIBUTION OF THIS SPECIES IN THE STATE AND MAY INCREASE THE TOTAL NUMBER OF KNOWN OCCURRENCES  THE FLORIDA NATURAL AREAS INVENTORY  FNAI  WILL CONDUCT BOTH COMPONENTS OF THIS WORK OVER A TWO YEAR PERIOD AND WILL EMPLOY WELL ESTABLISHED MONITORING METHODS DEVELOPED BY ARCHBOLD BIOLOGICAL STATION RESEARCHERS  THE INFORMATION GENERATED FROM THIS PROJECT WILL HELP THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE MAKE LISTING DECISIONS FOR THIS SPECIES AS WELL AS INFORM FUTURE RECOVERY ACTIONS SUCH AS HABITAT IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS AND TRANSLOCATION EFFORTS

THE DUGONG  DUGONG DUGON  IS AN AQUATIC HERBIVOROUS MAMMAL FOUND IN COASTAL WATERS OF THE TROPICS AND SUBTROPICS  PALAU S DISTINCT POPULATION OF DUGONGS, KNOWN AS MESEKIU, IS CULTURALLY ICONIC WITH A SUBSTANTIAL, BUT RELATIVELY UNDOCUMENTED HISTORY REGARDING ITS HUNTING AND VALUE IN THE TRADITIONAL SOCIAL HIERARCHY  PALAU S DUGONG POPULATION IS THE ONLY POPULATION IN MICRONESIA AND LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT ITS FEEDING HABITS AND MOVEMENTS  THE LACK OF INFORMATION ON SOCIAL VALUE AND ITS NATURAL HISTORY MAKES THE DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION OF EFFECTIVE PROTECTION POLICIES DIFFICULT  THIS PROJECT WILL INTEGRATE INTERVIEWS WITH ELDERS, COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT INCLUDING EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES AND MONITORING TO INFORM THE DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION OF CONSERVATION EFFORTS FOR DUGONGS  WE PROPOSE TO ENGAGE WITH ELDERS AND OTHERS IN THE COMMUNITY TO  1  BETTER UNDERSTAND TRADITIONAL KNOWLEDGE OF THE SPECIES, RANGE AND HABITS, 2  REVEAL PERCEPTIONS OF THREATS, 3  UNDERSTAND DIFFERENCES IN SOCIAL PERCEPTIONS BY AGE GROUP, 4  IDENTIFY OPPORTUNITIES TO IMPROVE SPECIES PROTECTION AND 5  INTEGRATE THIS INFORMATION INTO THE EBIIL S YOUTH RESEARCH PROGRAM  IN ADDITION, BASELINE SURVEYS TO DETERMINE NUMBER, INDIVIDUALS  IDENTIFIED BY MARKINGS ON SKIN  AND TEMPORAL PATTERNS OF FORAGING GROUPS  THE FWS WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE IN THE DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION OF DUGONG AEIRAL SURVEYS AND ECOLOGICAL MONITORING WITHIN KNOWN FEEDING GROUNDS

INVASIVE SPECIES ARE A LEADING THREAT TO CONSERVING BIODIVERSITY ACROSS THE NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE SYSTEM  INVASIVE SPECIES ARE THE MOST WIDESPREAD AND SERIOUS THREATS TO THE RESOURCES WITHIN THE PACIFIC SOUTHWEST REGION S 50 NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES  INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES ARE CONSIDERED THE BIGGEST THREAT TO THE SPECIALIZED HABITATS WITHIN THE GUADALUPE NIPOMO DUNES COMPLEX  REGIONAL INFESTATION OF EUROPEAN BEACHGRASS  AMMOPHILA ARENARIA  EBG  IS CAUSING A TYPE CONVERSION OF COASTAL DUNE SCRUB HABITATS TO NON NATIVE, PERENNIAL GRASSLAND THAT STABILIZES THE DYNAMIC AND ACTIVE DUNE SYSTEM  STABILIZATION OF THE DUNES DISRUPTS THE NATURAL ECOSYSTEM FUNCTIONS AND GEOMORPHIC PROCESSES, CAUSING A CASCADE OF DETRIMENTAL EFFECTS  EBG OCCUPIES NATURALLY OCCURRING VOIDS IN FOREDUNE VEGETATION AND, ONCE ESTABLISHED, FORMS UNNATURALLY STEEP, PARALLEL DUNES  IN ADDITION, BY CREATING CONTINUOUS, STEEP BARRIER DUNES IN PLACE OF NATURAL LOWER, DISCONTINUOUS DUNES, IT INCREASES OCEAN EROSION AND LIMITS THE DUNES NATURAL ABILITY TO ADAPT TO RISING SEA LEVEL  AS OF 2016, EBG COVERED 94 53 NET ACRES OF THE REFUGE OVER 511 08 GROSS ACRES OF INFESTED HABITAT  THANKS TO RECENT EFFORTS BY THE LAND CONSERVANCY OF SAN LUIS OBISPO COUNTY AND DIVERSE PEST MANAGEMENT INC  TO TREAT EBG ON THE REFUGE, THESE ACRES HAVE BEEN GREATLY REDUCED  THIS PROJECT WILL UPDATE THE MAPS OF EBG AND TREAT NON NATIVE VEGETATION ON THE REFUGE
