NATURAL DISTURBANCES, SUCH AS FLOODS, SEVERE WEATHER, AND WILDFIRE, HISTORICALLY PLAYED AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN DETERMINING THE DISTRIBUTION OF VEGETATION COMMUNITIES IN COASTAL MARSHES  HOWEVER, RISING SEA LEVELS, MILD WINTERS, AND FIRE SUPPRESSION HAVE ALTERED THE DISTURBANCE REGIMES IN COASTAL MARSHES, WITH CONSEQUENCES FOR THE HABITAT QUANTITY AND QUALITY OF MARSH DEPENDENT WILDLIFE  THUS, CONSERVATION OF THESE SPECIES IS LIKELY TO INCREASING DEPEND ON HUMAN INTERVENTION AS THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE ACCELERATE  IN ADDITION TO LARGER SCALE DISTURBANCES LIKE INUNDATION AND FIRE, TIDE DEPOSITED WRACK AND HERBIVORY BY TIDAL MACROINVERTEBRATES, SUCH AS CRABS, HAVE BEEN SHOWN TO FACILITATE THE ESTABLISHMENT OF DISTURBANCE DEPENDENT PLANTS AT SMALLER SCALES  ALONG THE COAST OF THE GULF OF MEXICO, WILDLIFE OF CONSERVATION CONCERN, SUCH AS EASTERN BLACK RAIL AND FLORIDA SALTMARSH VOLE, ARE POSITIVELY ASSOCIATED WITH THE PRESENCE OF THE DISTURBANCE DEPENDENT DISTICHLIS SPICATA  AS SUCH, MIMICKING THE EFFECTS OF WRACK DEPOSITION AND HERBIVORY MAY SERVE TO PROMOTE THE HABITAT CONDITIONS REQUIRED BY THESE MARSH ASSOCIATED SPECIES, WHILE ALSO BEING MORE FEASIBLE TO IMPLEMENT THAN LARGER SCALE DISTURBANCES  BY MECHANICALLY REMOVING VEGETATION AND DEPOSITING IN OTHER SECTIONS OF MARSH, WE WILL SIMULATE THE EFFECTS OF BOTH HERBIVORY AND WRACK DEPOSITION  BOTH BEFORE AND FOLLOWING THE ESTABLISHMENT OF THESE TREATMENTS, WE WILL MONITOR VEGETATION CONDITIONS AND MACROINVERTEBRATE ABUNDANCE  IN ADDITION, WE WILL MONITOR THE ACTIVITY OF BOTH EASTERN BLACK RAIL AND FLORIDA SALTMARSH VOLE TO DETERMINE THE EXTENT TO WHICH THESE SPECIES RESPOND TO THE TREATMENTS  THIS WORK WILL DETERMINE THE FEASIBILITY AND EFFICACY OF MANIPULATING SMALL SCALE DISTURBANCE IN COASTAL MARSHES TOWARD CONSERVING MARSH DEPENDENT SPECIES  SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL DEVELOP A TEMPLATE FOR MANAGERS LOOKING TO CONSERVE MARSH DEPENDENT SPECIES ACROSS THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES, WHILE ALSO FURTHERING OUR UNDERSTANDING OF HOW THESE SPECIES RESPOND TO DISTURBANCE AND THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE MORE BROADLY  GIVEN THE RECENT RANGE WIDE DECLINES OBSERVED FOR BOTH EASTERN BLACK RAIL AND FLORIDA SALTMARSH ROLE, THIS WORK COMES AT A CRITICAL TIME FOR MITIGATING THESE DECLINES AND ULTIMATELY CONSERVING THESE MARSH DEPENDENT SPECIES

ONE OF THE MAJOR THREATS TO COASTAL ENVIRONMENTS IS ACCELERATED RELATIVE SEA LEVEL RISE  SLR , A PREVALENT IMPACT OF CLIMATE CHANGE  NEW ENGLAND IS FACING SLR RATES THREE TO FOUR TIMES THE GLOBAL AVERAGE MAKING THIS REGION PARTICULARLY SUSCEPTIBLE TO SLR EFFECTS  INCREASED FLOODING CAUSED BY SLR, STORM SURGE, AND INCREASED PRECIPITATION EVENTS HAS LED TO THE LOSS OF COASTAL WETLANDS  COASTAL WETLANDS, SUCH AS SALT MARSHES, ARE CRITICAL TO MITIGATING IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND FLOODING, BUT ARE FACING COMPLEX DEGRADATION IMPACTS  SALT MARSHES SERVE AS A CARBON SINK, FOOD SOURCE, BREEDING HABITAT, AND NURSERY GROUND FOR BIRDS  INCLUDING THE VULNERABLE SALTMARSH SPARROW, AMMODRAMUS CAUDACUTUS , FISH, AND SHELLFISH  HANSON AND SHRIVER 2006   THESE ENVIRONMENTS ALSO PROVIDE FLOOD ABATEMENT AND HELP PREVENT COASTAL EROSION  BARBIER ET AL , 2011   HISTORICALLY, LATERAL TRANSGRESSION AND VERTICAL ACCRETION OF NEW ENGLAND SALT MARSHES HAVE BEEN ABLE TO KEEP PACE WITH SLR  RAPOSA ET AL , 2017   HOWEVER DUE TO INCREASED COASTAL DEVELOPMENT, LOW LYING COASTAL AREAS, REDUCED SEDIMENT SUPPLIES  CAUSED BY URBANIZATION, DAM CONSTRUCTION, AND REFORESTATION , AND ACCELERATING RATES OF SLR, NEW ENGLAND MARSHES ARE NO LONGER ABLE TO MIGRATE OR ACCRETE AT A RATE FAST ENOUGH TO WITHSTAND SLR IMPACTS  SALLENGER ET AL , 2012   HISTORIC HUMAN IMPACT, SUCH AS DITCH CREATION, HAS ALSO LOWERED SALT MARSH RESILIENCY TO SEA LEVEL RISE, PREVENTED MARSH DRAINAGE DUE TO DITCH CLOGGING, AND PROMOTED MARSH SUBSIDENCE  BURDICK ET AL  2020   AS A RESULT OF THESE IMPACTS, NEW ENGLAND SALT MARSHES HAVE SUFFERED FROM INCREASED DIEBACK AREAS, CHANGES IN VEGETATION COMPOSITION, VEGETATION LOSS, PEAT SUBSIDENCE, WATERLOGGED SOILS, AND PONDING  RAPOSA ET AL , 2017   THESE COMBINED EFFECTS FURTHER DECREASE SALT MARSH RESILIENCY TO STORMS AND CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS, WHICH THE NORTHEAST IS PARTICULARLY SUSCEPTIBLE TO  CROTTY ET AL , 2017   RESTORATION EFFORTS LIKE DITCH REMEDIATION AND RUNNEL IMPLEMENTATION ARE VALUABLE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES TO ENHANCE THE RESILIENCE OF SALT MARSHES TO SEA LEVEL RISE IMPACTS, PREVENT ANY FURTHER MARSH SUBSIDENCE, ENHANCE SALT MARSH ACCRETION, AND PROMOTE VEGETATION RECOLONIZATION THIS PROJECT FUNDING WILL SUPPORT A PORTION OF THE OVERALL DESIGN FOR SALT MARSH RESTORATION FOR THE 1100 ACRE SALT MARSH WITHIN THE SANDY NECK BARRIER BEACH SYSTEM  BARNSTABLE GREAT MARSH , WHICH WILL INCLUDE A VARIETY OF INNOVATIVE PRACTICES SUCH AS DITCH REMEDIATION, RUNNELS, AND MICRO TOPOGRAPHY   THE LOW RISK DITCH REMEDIATION METHOD INVOLVES THE HARVESTING OF SALTMARSH HAY ADJACENT TO DITCHES AND ITS PLACEMENT IN SELECTED DITCH BOTTOMS WHERE IT IS SECURED WITH TWINE  AS THE DITCH BOTTOM IS ELEVATED, NATURAL SALT MARSH VEGETATION COLONIZES AND COMPLETES THE RESTORATION OF THE DITCHES, STOPPING EXCESSIVE DRAINING AND MARSH SUBSIDENCE  RUNNELS ARE SHALLOW CHANNELS USED TO DRAIN WATER IMPOUNDMENTS THAT FORM ON THE MARSH SURFACE DUE TO SEA LEVEL RISE IMPACTS  THEY DRAIN STANDING WATER INTO NEARBY CREEKS OR DITCHES AND ENHANCE DRAINAGE PARTICULARLY WITHIN HIGH MARSH AREAS WHERE STANDING WATER IS CAUSING VEGETATION LOSS  THE DRAINAGE THAT RUNNELS PROVIDE ALLEVIATES FLOODING STRESS AND PROMOTES VEGETATION RECOLONIZATION  MICROTOPOGRAPHY OR MICRO ISLANDS IS AN INNOVATIVE TECHNIQUE USING SEDIMENT EXTRACTED FROM RUNNELS TO CREATE PEAT MOUNDS OF HIGHER ELEVATION THAT SALTMARSH SPARROWS CAN USE AS NESTING HABITAT FREE FROM FLOODING STRESS  RESTORATION DESIGN UTILIZING THESE TECHNIQUES WILL BE CONDUCTED STRATEGICALLY TO REPLICATE NATURAL HYDROLOGY, RESTORING MARSH HEALTH AND ITS ABILITY TO KEEP PACE WITH SLR THROUGH REVERSING MARSH SUBSIDENCE AND INCREASING ACCRETION RATES

ANCHOR OUT FOR SAFETY AND SALMON   THIS SLOGAN IS PART OF AN INNOVATIVE LOCALLY DRIVEN VOLUNTARY NO ANCHOR ZONE APPROACH TO PROTECT AND RESTORE NATIVE EELGRASS BEDS IN PUGET SOUND  EELGRASS MEADOWS PROVIDE CRITICAL HABITAT AND ECOSYSTEM SERVICES  ONE OF THE GREATEST CAUSES OF LOCALIZED EELGRASS DECLINE IS PHYSICAL DAMAGE CAUSED BY VESSELS, SPECIFICALLY ANCHOR SCOUR AND PROPELLER STRIKES  CUMULATIVE IMPACTS OF THESE PHYSICAL STRESSORS HAVE LASTING EFFECTS ON THE HEALTH AND RESILIENCE OF EELGRASS BEDS  INFORMATIONAL BUOYS ESTABLISHING VOLUNTARY NO ANCHOR ZONES ARE A PROVEN METHOD TO PROTECT EELGRASS FROM VESSEL DAMAGE BY PROVIDING BOATERS WITH A VISUAL CUE AND SOCIAL PROMPT TO ANCHOR OUTSIDE OF EELGRASS BEDS  THIS PROJECT WILL ESTABLISH VOLUNTARY NO ANCHOR ZONES FROM A CURRENT LIST OF EIGHT POTENTIAL SITES, SUPPORT MONITORING OF EXISTING SITES, AND IMPLEMENT REGIONAL COORDINATION AND MESSAGING TO PROMOTE PROPER USE OF NO ANCHOR ZONES  THE PROJECT SCOPE OF WORK INCLUDES SITE SELECTION, ALL NECESSARY PERMITTING, EELGRASS AND VESSEL COMPLIANCE SURVEYS, AND A SOCIAL MARKETING CAMPAIGN  PROJECT PARTNERS WILL ALSO BE CONVENED TO BUILD A LASTING REGIONAL PROGRAM THAT CONTINUES TO MAINTAIN AND EXPAND SITES BEYOND THE DURATION OF THIS GRANT  WITH THE PARTNERSHIP OF LOCAL MARINE RESOURCES COMMITTEES  MRCS , NONPROFIT PARTNERS, LOCAL PORTS, AND STATE AGENCIES, THIS PROJECT WILL GREATLY EXPAND AN EFFECTIVE STRATEGY FOR EELGRASS PROTECTION THAT IS ROOTED IN LOCALLY DRIVEN STEWARDSHIP

IN THE SPRING OF 2002, A GROUP OF AGENCY, ADVOCACY, AND INDUSTRY PARTNERS MET TO ADDRESS THE ISSUE OF HABITAT LOSS IN DICKINSON BAY AND TO EVALUATE THE POTENTIAL TO RESTORE THREE LOST ISLANDS  HISTORICALLY, AND BEFORE SIGNIFICANT SUBSIDENCE AND EROSION OCCURRED, THE ISLANDS SUPPORTED NESTING BIRD SPECIES, INCLUDING LEAST TERN, GULL BILLED TERN, ROYAL TERN, BLACK SKIMMER, AMERICAN OYSTERCATCHER, AND CASPIAN TERN, AS WELL AS INTERTIDAL MARSH HABITAT  THE FIRST ISLAND, DICKINSON BAY BIRD ISLAND I  DBI , WAS CONSTRUCTED IN 2005, AND CONSISTS OF A 5 ACRE, HORSESHOE SHAPED CLAY ISLAND PROTECTED WITH A RIP RAP REVETMENT WITH MARSH MOUNDS IN THE INTERIOR PLUS A 2 ACRE OYSTER REEF ADJACENT TO THE ISLAND  SINCE CONSTRUCTION, DBI HAS BEEN SURVEYED ANNUALLY AS PART OF THE TEXAS COLONIAL WATERBIRD SURVEYS  CURRENTLY, THE SITE PROVIDES ROOKERY HABITAT FOR A VARIETY OF SPECIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO  BROWN PELICAN, AMERICAN OYSTERCATCHER, CATTLE EGRET, ROSEATE SPOONBILL, TRI COLORED HERON, SNOWY EGRET, GREAT BLUE HERON, GREAT EGRET, WHITE IBIS, CASPIAN, ROYAL, FORSTER S TERNS, NEOTROPICAL CORMORANT, AND LAUGHING GULL SINCE CONSTRUCTION, DBI HAS WEATHERED SEVERAL TROPICAL WEATHER EVENTS INCLUDING HURRICANES IKE  2008 , HURRICANE HARVEY  2017 , LAURA  2020  NICHOLAS  2021  AND TROPICAL STORMS IMELDA  2019  AND BETA  2020   THE WEATHER EVENTS OCCURRING IN 2020 AND 2021  LAURA, NICHOLAS, BETA  ALL MADE LANDFALL EAST OF THE GALVESTON BAY COMPLEX AND THE NORTH, NORTHEAST WIND DRIVEN WAVES RESULTING FROM THESE STORMS CAUSED SIGNIFICANT DAMAGE TO DBI  DBI HAS A LARGE FETCH TO THE NORTH OF THE ISLAND ALLOWING THE STORM GENERATED WAVE ENERGY TO BUILD PRIOR TO IMPACTING THE ISLAND  THE RESULT IS THE EASTERN LEVEE OF THE ISLAND S HORSESHOE SHAPE, EXPERIENCED EROSION, LOSS OF VEGETATION, LOSS OF ELEVATION, AND PORTIONS OF THE RIP RAP REVETMENT WERE DAMAGED OR WASHED OVER THE LEVEE AND NO LONGER PROVIDE PROTECTION ON THE EASTERN SIDE OF THE ISLAND  THIS DAMAGE, IF NOT REPAIRED, COULD LEAVE DBI MORE VULNERABLE TO FUTURE STORMS AND HIGH WAVE ENERGY EVENTS  CONTINUED EROSION AND LOSS OF ELEVATION COULD EVENTUALLY LEAD TO THE LOSS OF CRITICAL ROOKERY HABITAT IN THE GALVESTON BAY REGION THE PROJECT WILL COLLECT DATA ON THE CURRENT CONDITION OF THE ISLAND AND FURTHER STABILIZE THE ISLAND, PRIMARILY THE EASTERN LEVEE, BY ADDING MATERIAL AND OR ADDITIONAL RIP RAP REVETMENT  MEASURE MAY ALSO BE TAKEN TO REMOVE UNDESIRED VEGETATION AND PLANT MORE DESIRABLE VEGETATION FOR APPROPRIATE COLONIAL WATERBIRD NESTING HABITAT

THE PACIFIC COAST POPULATION OF WESTERN SNOWY PLOVERS  CHARADRIUS NIVOSUS NIVOSUS  IS A FEDERALLY LISTED THREATENED AND STATE LISTED ENDANGERED SPECIES KNOWN TO NEST IN THREE AREAS ALONG THE WASHINGTON COAST  LEADBETTER POINT, NORTH COVE AND MIDWAY BEACH  IN 2020 FIVE JUVENILE PLOVERS FLEDGED FROM THREE BROODS AT COPALIS SPIT IN THE SEASHORE CONSERVATION AREA  SCA  ADJACENT TO GRIFFITHS PRIDAY STATE PARK, THE FIRST SUCCESSFUL NESTING AT THE SITE SINCE 1984  SUCCESSFUL NESTING WAS CONCENTRATED AT THE NORTH END OF COPALIS SPIT WHICH IS AGGRADING, CREATING NEWLY ACCRETED BEACH WITH A LOW PROFILE, OPEN SAND, AND LOW VEGETATIVE COVER SUITABLE FOR NESTING BY SNOWY PLOVERS  HOWEVER, NON NATIVE BEACHGRASS  AMMOPHILA SPP   IS SPREADING INTO THE AREA, TRANSITIONING THE SPIT TO A DENSE BEACHGRASS DOMINATED SYSTEM WITH A FOREDUNE AND STEEP BEACH PROFILE NOT SUITABLE FOR PLOVER NESTING  THIS PROJECT WILL CONTROL BEACHGRASS IN THE AREA CURRENTLY USED FOR NESTING BY PLOVERS AND, AS FUNDING IS AVAILABLE, PUSH BACK THE BEACHGRASS TO THE EAST TO CREATE A LARGER AREA SUITABLE FOR NESTING

THE TEXAS COLONIAL WATERBIRD SOCIETY (TCWS) IS COMPRISED OF FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES, UNIVERSITIES AND NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS WHO MEET ANNUALLY TO PLAN AND CONDUCT THE COLONIAL WATERBIRD BREEDING SURVEY EACH YEAR. IN MAY 2016, WITH FUNDING FROM THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (FWS), THE HARTE RESEARCH INSTITUTE (HRI) BEGAN ADDRESSING THE MANAGEMENT OF THE DATABASE THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF A WEB APPLICATION FOR VIEWING AND ENTERING DATA, TRANSFORMING THE DATABASE TO A GEODATABASE FORMAT, AND SCANNING ORIGINAL FIELD FORMS. WHILE MOST OF THIS WORK IS COMPLETED, MORE INTERACTION WITH TCWS REPRESENTATIVES IS NEEDED TO TEST AND ADAPT THE WEB APPLICATIONS TO USER NEEDS AND TO ADDRESS ISSUES WITH SOME EXISTING DATA RECORDS. ADDITIONALLY, UPDATES TO THE DATABASE WITH THE LATEST DATA IS REQUIRED.HRI WILL WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE FWS AND TCWS TO COMPLETE, IMPROVE, AND DEPLOY THE SPATIAL WEB-BASED DATA ENTRY AND RETRIEVAL PORTAL FOR TEXAS COLONIAL WATERBIRD SURVEY DATA. THE PROPOSED WORK WILL INCLUDE THE CLEANUP OF THE EXISTING DATABASE, ADDING MISSING SURVEY YEARS, CREATE A MOBILE/WEB DATA ENTRY APPLICATION, FINALIZE A WEB MAP APPLICATION, AND ESTABLISH A DATA ACCESS PORTAL THAT SUPPORTS PUBLIC ACCESS TO THE INFORMATION IN THE DATABASE. THE SERVICE WILL PROVIDE LIAISON SUPPORT BETWEEN HRI AND THE TCWS, COORDINATE AND FACILITATE MEETINGS WITH TCWS MEMBERS AND STAKEHOLDERS.

THE NORTHWEST STRAITS FOUNDATION, WSHINGTON STATE PARKS, AND THE SKAGIT AND WHATCOM COUNTY MARINE RESOURCES COMMITTEES (MRCS) ARE PARTNERS TO DEVELOP A FEASIBILITY STUDY, DESIGN, PERMITTING, AND INITIATE COMMUNITY OUTREACH FOR RESTORATION OF OVER 1,200 LINEAR FEET OF SHORELINE, 9 ACRES OF BACKSHORE, AND ADJACENT UPLAND HABITAT AT CLAYTON BEACH IN LARRABEE STATE PARK, SKAGIT COUNTY, WA. THE NEARSHORE HABITAT AND PROCESSES AT THE SITE ARE DEGRADED AND IMPEDED BY RIPRAP, PILINGS, AND DEBRIS - ALL REMNANTS OF THE INTERURBAN TROLLEY TRESTLE THAT RAN BETWEEN BELLINGHAM AND MOUNT VERNON FROM 1912 TO 1928. THE REMAINING STUBS PRESENT ALONG THE BEACH REPRESENT JUST SOME OF THE 5,000 PILINGS USED TO BUILD THE TRESTLE. THE ARMOR AT THIS SITE IS UNIQUELY SITUATED WITHIN THE MID-INTERTIDAL CREATING A PERCHED BEACH, IMPEDING SEDIMENT TRANSPORT ALONGSHORE, AND DIRECTLY BURYING INTERTIDAL HABITAT AND FORAGE FISH SPAWNING HABITAT. REMOVAL OF THE SHORE ARMOR WILL RESTORE THE CONNECTION BETWEEN NEARSHORE HABITATS AND THE BACKSHORE ALLOWING FOR GREATER EXCHANGE OF TERRESTRIAL AND AQUATIC NUTRIENTS, INSECTS AND ORGANIC MATTER. RESTORING THIS CONNECTION WILL PROVIDE A SOURCE OF INSECTS CRITICAL IN THE DIET OF JUVENILE SALMONIDS AND THE PREY OF MIGRATING BULL TROUT, AS WELL AS IMPROVED FORAGING HABITAT FOR MARINE AND SHORE BIRDS. THE SHORELINE WILL BECOME MORE COMPLEX AND ABLE TO RECRUIT AND STORE LARGE WOODY DEBRIS, AS THE ARMOR WILL NOT REFLECT THE WOOD OFF THE SHORE. REMOVAL AND RESTORATION WILL ALSO ALLOW FOR LANDWARD EXPANSION OF THE EELGRASS BED THAT IS LIMITED BY THE LOW ELEVATION OF THE ARMOR.

THE CARPINTERIA SALT MARSH IS A 230-ACRE WETLAND LOCATED IN SOUTHERN SANTA BARBARA COUNTY IMMEDIATELY TO THE WEST  OF THE CITY OF CARPINTERIA, CALIFORNIA. ONE OF THE FEW HIGH-FUNCTIONING COASTAL SALT MARSHES REMAINING IN  SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA, THE CARPINTERIA SALT MARSH PROVIDES SEVERAL IMPORTANT ECOLOGICAL GOODS AND SERVICES  INCLUDING COASTAL FLOOD PROTECTION, BIOFILTRATION, AND THE PROVISION OF ESSENTIAL HABITAT FOR NUMEROUS SPECIES OF  NATIVE WETLAND PLANTS, FISHES, INVERTEBRATES, AND BIRDS. THE MARSH RECEIVES WATERS FROM THREE CREEKS ORIGINATING  IN THE FOOTHILLS OF THE SANTA YNEZ MOUNTAINS, FRANKLIN CREEK, SANTA MONICA CREEK AND A SMALLER UN-NAMED CREEK  ENTERING THE MARSH ALONG ITS WESTERN BOUNDARY, AND HAS A SINGLE OPENING TO THE PACIFIC OCEAN.EUROPEAN SEA LAVENDER (LIMONIUM DURIUSCULUM) IS INVASIVE IN COASTAL SALT MARSHES IN CALIFORNIA. THE INVASIVE,  NON-NATIVE EUROPEAN SEA LAVENDER CAN BE FOUND GROWING WITHIN THE CARPINTERIA SALT MARSH AT ELEVATIONS JUST ABOVE  THE MEAN HIGH TIDE LINE. EUROPEAN SEA LAVENDER HAS BEEN IN THE MARSH SINCE 2003 AND HAS NOW SPREAD TO SEVERAL  AREAS LOCATED THROUGHOUT THE MARSH. SPECIES OF NATIVE WETLAND PLANTS GROWING IN THE IMPACTED AREAS INCLUDE:  PICKLEWEED, MARSH JAUMEA (JAUMEA CARNOSA), AND SALT MARSH BIRD'S-BEAK. SALT MARSH BIRD'S-BEAK IS A STATE AND  FEDERALLY ENDANGERED HEMIPARASITIC ANNUAL PLANT THAT GROWS IN UPPER INTERTIDAL AREAS OF COASTAL SALT MARSHES.  NON-NATIVE LIMONIUM IS CONSIDERED A MAJOR THREAT TO SALT MARSH BIRD'S-BEAK AND IS PRESENT AT 6 OF THE 7 SOUTHERN  CALIFORNIA SALT MARSH SYSTEMS THAT ARE OCCUPIED BY SALT MARSH BIRD'S-BEAK (USFWS 2020). THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF  THIS PROJECT IS TO TREAT NEW AREAS AND RE-TREAT AREAS THAT HAVE PREVIOUSLY BEEN TREATED FOR NON-NATIVE LIMONIUM  AT CARPINTERIA SALT MARSH. THIS PROJECT WILL TREAT A MINIMUM 2 NET ACRES OF LIMONIUM WITH THE POTENTIAL TO  BENEFIT MORE ACRES WITHIN THE SALT MARSH. THE PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL BENEFIT NATIVE MARSH VEGETATION, INCLUDING  THE LISTED SALT MARSH BIRD'S-BEAK, AS WELL AS OTHER FEDERAL TRUST RESOURCES. IN ADDITION, THE PROJECT WILL  IMPROVE HABITAT IN THE SALT MARSH FOR STUDENTS AND OTHER VISITORS TO THE MARSH.

THE PROJECT WILL RESTORE LANDSCAPE-SCALE HYDROLOGIC CONDITIONS AND FACILITATE NATURAL FLOOD MANAGEMENT IN THE MARENGO RIVER WATERSHED (MRW). THE PROJECT WILL COMPLEMENT FARM AND IN-STREAM CONSERVATION PRACTICES TO REDUCE PEAK FLOWS AND TREAT NUTRIENT RUNOFF. THE PROJECT WILL RECONSTRUCT THE BERWEGER ROAD CULVERT TO RESTORE NATURAL FLOWS AND RE-ESTABLISH FLOOD STORAGE CAPACITY IN DEGRADED WETLANDS. THE CULVERT WILL BE SIZED TO ACCOMMODATE CHANGING CLIMATIC HYDROLOGIC CONDITIONS. RECONSTRUCTION OF THIS CULVERT AND IMPROVED STREAM CHANNEL FLOW IS FUNDAMENTAL TO THE GREATER LANDSCAPE-SCALE HYDROLOGIC RESTORATION (NFM) STRATEGY. WITHOUT THIS FUNDING, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL NOT BE ABLE TO ACHIEVE DESIRED CHANNEL FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY AND WETLAND IMPROVEMENT. THE CULVERT RECONSTRUCTION WILL BENEFIT WESTERN LAKE SUPERIOR FOCAL SPECIES SUCH AS MUDPUPPY. THE ADJACENT WETLAND COMPLEX WILL BE ENHANCED AND PROTECTED THROUGH RESTORED STREAM FLOW AND SEDIMENT REDUCTION, THUS BENEFITTING FOCAL SPECIES INCLUDING BLUE-WINGED TEAL AND CANADA WARBLERS. SEDIMENT REDUCTION WILL IMPROVE DOWNSTREAM WATER QUALITY AND SPAWNING HABITAT FOR TRIBALLY SIGNIFICANT FISH SPECIES INCLUDING LAKE STURGEON.GOALS INCLUDE: ENHANCE SURFACE WATER RESOURCES, REDUCE NON-POINT POLLUTION TO THE MARENGO RIVER AND LAKE SUPERIOR, IMPLEMENT PROJECTS TO DEMONSTRATE SLOW-THE-FLOW AND FLOOD ADAPTATION PRACTICES, AND REPLACE BERWEGER ROAD CULVERTS WITH ONE BOX CULVERT. THE PROJECT SERVES A FINANCIALLY DEPRESSED ECONOMIC AND FLOOD-PRONE REGION. DELIVERABLES INCLUDE: 60 ACRES WETLAND RESTORED; 6 MILES STREAM RESTORED; AND 10 OUTREACH EFFORTS: TOURS, SITE VISITS, AND ARTICLES PROVIDED.

THE COASTAL PROGRAM, LAGUNA ATASCOSA NWR, AND LOCAL PARTNERS ARE INTERESTED IN RESTORING WETLAND HABITATS IN CAMERON COUNTY, TEXAS WITH THE GOAL OF IMPROVING WETLAND HEALTH AND INCREASING WETLAND FUNCTION ON THE REFUGE FOR WILDLIFE RESOURCES, FLOOD STORAGE, AND WATER QUALITY  AS AN INITIAL STEP TOWARDS ACHIEVING THIS GOAL, THE COASTAL PROGRAM AND DU WANTS TO INITIATE PROJECT PLANNING ACTIONS THAT WILL RESULT IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF CONCEPT OR PRELIMINARY RESTORATION PLANS WITH PROJECT DESIGNS FOR PRIORITY WETLANDS  THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE IS TO DEVELOP CONCEPTUAL OR PRELIMINARY ENGINEERING AND DESIGN PRODUCTS FOR PRIORITY WETLAND SITES  DUCKS UNLIMITED WILL PARTNER WITH THE COASTAL PROGRAM, REFUGE STAFF, AND LOCAL PARTNERS TO ACCOMPLISH PROJECT OBJECTIVES  SERVICES PROVIDED BY DU WILL INCLUDE FIELD SURVEYS AND PRELIMINARY ENGINEERING AND DESIGN PRODUCTS

COLLISIONS BETWEEN BIRDS AND AIRCRAFT CAN HAVE SEVERE COSTS IN BOTH PROPERTY AND LOSS OF LIFE. PROPER MANAGEMENT OF ON-AIRFIELD VEGETATION IS WIDELY ACCEPTED TO BE A CRITICAL COMPONENT TO REDUCING THE RISK OF SUCH COLLISIONS, OFTEN TERMED BIRD/WILDLIFE AIR STRIKE HAZARD (BASH). MOST DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE (DOD) AIRFIELDS MAINTAIN AIRFIELD VEGETATION AT 7-14 INCHES THROUGHOUT THE YEAR THROUGH REGULAR MOWING (E.G., AIR FORCE PAMPHLET 91-212). THIS HEIGHT RANGE (7-14 INCHES) IS ASSUMED TO BE TOO TALL FOR FLOCKING SPECIES, BUT TOO SHORT TO PRODUCE SEEDS AND HARBOR RODENTS THAT ATTRACT OTHER HAZARDOUS WILDLIFE (AIR FORCE PAMPHLET 91-212). HOWEVER, STUDIES INVESTIGATING THE EFFECT OF VEGETATION HEIGHT ON HAZARDOUS SPECIES ABUNDANCE HAVE FREQUENTLY BEEN INCONCLUSIVE. MOST PREVIOUS STUDIES HAVE LACKED A RANDOMIZED CONTROLLED DESIGN, HAD LOW REPLICATION, OR FAILED TO ACCOUNT FOR BIASES DUE TO IMPERFECT DETECTION. WE PROPOSE A RIGOROUS EVALUATION OF BIRD RESPONSE TO VEGETATION MANAGEMENT REGIMES ON THE TEST SITE AIRFIELD, LAKEHURST (JBMDL) USING A CONTROLLED EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN AND DISTANCE-SAMPLING FRAMEWORK, WITH POTENTIAL APPLICATIONS TO OTHER DOD AIRFIELDS. WE WILL CONDUCT SURVEYS AT THE SITE TO QUANTIFY AND OCCUPANCY BY GRASSLAND BIRD SPECIES, INCLUDING NJ-LISTED THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES SUCH AS GRASSHOPPER SPARROW (AMMODRAMUS SAVANNARUM) AND UPLAND SANDPIPER (BARTRAMIA LONGICAUDA) IN AREAS THAT ARE MOWED TO MAINTAIN THE GRASS AT A HEIGHT OF 7-14 INCHES COMPARED TO AREAS WHERE THE GRASS IS NOT MOWED UNTIL THE CONCLUSION OF THE GROWING SEASON IN LATE SEPTEMBER. THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE TO LOOK AT DIFFERENCES BETWEEN THE TWO TREATMENT AREAS IN PROVIDING HABITAT THAT IS USED BY GRASSLAND BIRDS.

THIS PROJECT IS A COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE SMITH RIVER ALLIANCE (SRA) AND THE ARCATA COASTAL PROGRAM TO RESTORE FOUR ACRES OF COASTAL WETLAND HABITAT IN LOWER ELK CREEK, A SMALL COASTAL TRIBUTARY TO THE PACIFIC OCEAN IN CRESCENT CITY, CALIFORNIA. THE ELK CREEK WATERSHED IS LOCATED ON THE COASTAL PLAIN ADJACENT TO CRESCENT CITY AND INCLUDES THE WESTERN SLOPE OF THE COAST RANGE MOUNTAINS. THE PROJECT REACH IS LOCATED ON THE MAINSTEM OF ELK CREEK, BEGINNING APPROXIMATELY 1.13 MILES UPSTREAM FROM THE MOUTH AT THE PACIFIC OCEAN. THIS REACH IS JUST UPSTREAM FROM AN OXBOW POND AND THE CONFLUENCE WITH THE LARGE SOUTH TRIBUTARY OF ELK CREEK. THE PROPERTY IS LOCATED ON A BROAD LOW-GRADIENT FLOODPLAIN FLANKED BY CDFW-MANAGED LANDS ON THE WEST, SOUTH, AND EAST SIDES, AND CONTAINS FRESHWATER AND TIDAL WETLANDS WITH UPLAND FORESTS PRIMARILY AROUND THE MARGINS.THE ELK CREEK RESTORATION FEASIBILITY STUDY DOCUMENTED JUVENILE SALMONIDS INCLUDING ESA-LISTED SONCC COHO SALMON AND COASTAL CUTTHROAT TROUT REARING IN THE LOWER WATERSHED AND IDENTIFIED A LACK OF STREAM COMPLEXITY AND OFF-CHANNEL HABITAT AS A LIMITING FACTOR. THE LOWER ELK CREEK WATERSHED CONSISTS OF A COMPLEX OF MAINSTEM CHANNELS, TRIBUTARIES, CONVEYANCE CROSS CHANNELS, DRAINAGE DITCHES, AND PONDS. MANY OF THESE HYDROLOGIC FEATURES, INCLUDING THE PROJECT REACH, HAVE BEEN ANTHROPOGENICALLY SIMPLIFIED, STRAIGHTENED, AND DIKED OVER THE PAST CENTURY.THE DESIGN GOAL IS TO INSTALL FOUR PAIRS OF STRUCTURES TOTALING EIGHT BDAS. THE BDAS WILL BE PLACED IN A HYDRAULICALLY SUITABLE LOCATION ALONG THE MAINSTEM OF ELK CREEK WHERE THE RELATIVELY SMALL CHANNEL SIZE WILL FACILITATE CONSTRUCTABILITY AND MULTI-THREAD PLANFORM CAN ACCOMMODATE FISH PASSAGE ALONG MULTIPLE FLOW PATHS. THE PROJECT WILL ENHANCE APPROXIMATELY 300 TO 400 LINEAR FEET OF HABITAT, INCREASE SURFACE FLOW CONNECTION TO APPROXIMATELY 3 TO 4 ACRES OF OFF-CHANNEL WETLAND HABITAT, AND WILL PROVIDE BUILDING SITES FOR BEAVER IN THE ELK CREEK WATERSHED TO MAINTAIN OR MODIFY. THE GOAL WILL BE TO MIMIC AND PROMOTE WOOD ACCUMULATION AND BEAVER DAM ACTIVITY.

BIG BOGGY NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE AND THE USFWS COASTAL PROGRAM IS INTERESTED IN RESTORING VEGETATED MARSH AND OVERALL CONNECTIVITY TO THE 1,800-AC BIG BOGGY MARSH SYSTEM THROUGH MULTIPLE ACTIONS. THESE ACTIONS WOULD RESTORE AND IMPROVE MARSH VEGETATION HEALTH, SUPPORT LONG TERM RESILIENCY OF THE MARSH, INCREASE ITS FUNCTIONALITY FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES, AND ENHANCE THE PRODUCTION OF THESE RESOURCES BEYOND THE MARSH INTO EAST MATAGORDA BAY. THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL BE CONCEPTUAL OR PRELIMINARY DESIGN DELIVERABLES FOR PRIORITY RESTORATION ACTIONS IDENTIFIED BY THE PROJECT TEAM. GENERALLY, SERVICES PROVIDED BY DUCKS UNLIMITED WILL INCLUDE ELEVATION AND HORIZONTAL SURVEYS, ENGINEERING AND DESIGN, AND ASSISTANCE IN PROJECT PLANNING AND COORDINATION. SERVICE STAFF WILL BE SUBSTANTIALLY INVOLVED IN THE PROJECT BY PROVIDING TECHNICAL GUIDANCE ON DESIRED OUTCOMES, DRAFTING PROPOSALS TO SUPPORT ADDITIONAL FUNDING, COORDINATING AND COMMUNICATING WITH STATE, FEDERAL, AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS ABOUT THE PURPOSE AND NEED FOR THE PROJECT, APPLYING THE BEST AVAILABLE SCIENCE FOR THE PROJECT, PROVIDING ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLIANCE DOCUMENTATION AND PARTICIPATING IN MEETINGS WITH RESOURCE STAKEHOLDERS ASSOCIATED WITH EAST MATAGORDA BAY. THERE ARE NO PRE-AWARD COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH THIS PROJECT.

THE PREDATOR MANAGEMENT PROJECT DESCRIBED IN THE DAMAGE ASSESSMENT AND RESTORATION PLANFOR THE NEW CARISSA OIL SPILL WAS ESTIMATED TO RESTORE 29,292 BIRD-YEARS AND WAS BASED ON THEEXPECTATION OF A SIGNIFICANT INCREASE IN SEABIRD PRODUCTIVITY ONCE RED FOX WERE REMOVED FROMSEABIRD COLONIES IN SOUTHERN OREGON. FOXES WERE LARGELY ELIMINATED FROM THE AREA BEFORE THEPREDATOR MANAGEMENT PROJECT BEGAN. AS A RESULT, THE NUMBER OF BIRD-YEARS GENERATED BY THISPROJECT TO-DATE ARE LESS THAN ANTICIPATED. RESTARTING THE PREDATOR MANAGEMENT PROJECT WILLALLOW TRUSTEES TO ADDRESS THIS OUTSTANDING, UNCOMPENSATED DEBT. ONE AREA OF PARTICULARCONCERN IS SADDLE ROCK (CROOK POINT), WHICH ONCE CONTAINED A LARGE COLONY OF LEACH'S STORMPETRELS.IN RECENT YEARS, STORM-PETREL NUMBERS HAVE FALLEN DRAMATICALLY AT THIS SITE. VIA THEPREDATOR MANAGEMENT PROJECT, SADDLE ROCK AND OTHER NEARBY COLONIES WILL BE MONITORED FORSIGNS OF PREDATION AND SUBSEQUENT PREDATOR CONTROL ACTIONS TAKEN. EFFORTS WILL FOCUS ON ISLANDSIN THE VICINITY OF COQUILLE POINT, CROOK POINT AND HARRIS BEACH. PRE/POST NESTING SEASON SEARCHESFOR EVIDENCE OF PREDATORS AND PREDATION (SCAT CONTAINING FEATHERS, BIRD CARCASSES, NESTDESTRUCTION, ETC.,) WILL OCCUR ON ALL ISLANDS. SCATS WILL BE COLLECTED FOR GENETIC ANALYSIS TODETERMINE WHETHER CERTAIN SPECIES (E.G., VOLES) ARE PREYING ON STORM-PETRELS. MOTION DETECTINGCAMERAS WILL BE PLACED STRATEGICALLY ALONG TRAILS, HEADLANDS, AND WITHIN SEABIRD COLONIES TODOCUMENT PREDATOR PRESENCE AND PREDATION EVENTS. MONTHLY DRONE SURVEYS OF OFF-SHORE ROCKSWILL COMPLIMENT MONITORING OF PREDATION. SHOULD MONITORING INDICATE THAT PREDATORS ARE HAVINGA DETRIMENTAL EFFECT ON NESTING SEABIRDS, FWS WILL IMPLEMENT A FOCUSED TRAPPING EFFORT TOREMOVE PROBLEM ANIMALS. OSU STAFF WILL BE TRAINED BY WILDLIFE SERVICES ON HOW TO SET ANDMAINTAIN TRAPS. TRAPS WILL BE CHECKED DAILY. CAPTURED ANIMALS WILL BE EUTHANIZED IN A HUMANEMANNER. BY RESTARTING THE PREDATOR MANAGEMENT PROJECT, FWS HOPES TO FURTHER REDUCEPREDATION PRESSURES AT SEVERAL KEY LOCATIONS ALONG THE COAST WHERE PREDATION CONTINUES TOOCCUR. THIS WILL ALLOW TRUSTEES TO ADDRESS THE REMAINING, UNCOMPENSATED DEBT FOR SEABIRDS, ANDMAKE THE RESOURCE AND PUBLIC WHOLE FOR LOST NATURAL RESOURCE SERVICES RESULTING FROM THE NEWCARISSA SPILL.

GLACIERLAND RESOURCE CONSERVATION & DEVELOPMENT COUNCIL, INC. (GLACIERLAND) IS PARTNERING WITH LOCAL MUNICIPALITIES, SCHOOL DISTRICTS AND NGOS TO RESTORE AND MAINTAIN HIGH-QUALITY, RESILIENT NATURAL HABITAT WITHIN COASTAL AND NEAR-COASTAL AREAS ALONG THE LAKE MICHIGAN SHORELINE, THAT WILL SUPPORT SUSTAINABLE POPULATIONS OF MIGRATORY AND RESIDENT BIRDS, POLLINATORS, MAMMALS, AND OTHER WILDLIFE IN MANITOWOC COUNTY, WISCONSIN. GLACIERLAND WILL WORK WITH PROJECT PARTNERS TO DEVELOP COMMUNITY-FOCUSED MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR SIX PROPERTIES, COVERING A TOTAL OF 758 ACRES WHICH WILL PROVIDE THE PLANNING FRAMEWORK FOR LONG-TERM, SUSTAINED CONTROL. MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES WILL TARGET INVASIVE CONTROL ENHANCEMENT AND RESTORATION TASKS ACROSS A TOTAL OF 300 ACRES OF WILDLIFE HABITAT. RESTORATION WILL MITIGATE THE IMPACTS OF EMERALD ASH BORER, SPECIFICALLY LOSS OF TREE CANOPY AND WILL INCREASE RESILIENCE OF NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITIES TO CLIMATE CHANGE AND OTHER STRESSORS THROUGH THE PLANTING OF CLIMATE-ADAPTED NATIVE HERBACEOUS, SHRUB, AND TREE SPECIES. ENGAGEMENT OF LOCAL RESIDENTS AND STUDENTS WILL ENHANCE UNDERSTANDING OF THE VALUE OF HABITAT RESTORATION FOR WILDLIFE AND MIGRATORY BIRDS AND DEVELOP COMMITMENT TO LONG-TERM SITE STEWARDSHIP, INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL, VEGETATION ENHANCEMENT, AND MONITORING.

THE PROJECT WILL TAKE A MULTI-PRONGED APPROACH TO ENSURE AWARENESS OF THE COASTAL RESTORATION, COASTAL RESOURCES AND THE BENEFITS OF HEALTH COASTAL ECOSYSTEMS FOR EVERYONE. RAE WILL PARTNER WITH FWS TO FOSTER COMMUNITY OF PRACTICE AMONG ORGANIZATIONS WORKING IN COASTAL ECOSYSTEMS, EDUCATE PRACTITIONERS AND POLICYMAKERS ABOUT THE IMPORTANCE OF COASTAL AND ESTUARINE RESOURCES AND HOW BEST TO PROTECT, RESTORE AND COMMUNICATE ABOUT THEM. THIS YEAR, THERE WILL BE SPECIAL FOCUS ON UNDERSTANDING HOW THE COASTAL PROGRAM CAN BETTER SERVE URBAN COMMUNITIES AND HISTORICALLY UNDERREPRESENTED COMMUNITIES VIA RESEARCH AND FOCUS GROUPS THAT WILL HELP BETTER COMMUNICATION THE CURRENT BENEFITS OF THE PROGRAM AND GUIDE THE FUTURE PROGRAM.

IN THE SPRING OF 2002, A GROUP OF AGENCY, ADVOCACY, AND INDUSTRY PARTNERS MET TO ADDRESS THE ISSUE OF HABITAT LOSS IN DICKINSON BAY AND TO EVALUATE THE POTENTIAL TO RESTORE THREE LOST ISLANDS. HISTORICALLY, AND BEFORE SIGNIFICANT SUBSIDENCE AND EROSION OCCURRED, THE ISLANDS SUPPORTED NESTING BIRD SPECIES, INCLUDING LEAST TERN, GULL-BILLED TERN, ROYAL TERN, BLACK SKIMMER, AMERICAN OYSTERCATCHER, AND CASPIAN TERN, AS WELL AS INTERTIDAL MARSH HABITAT. THE FIRST ISLAND (DICKINSON BAY BIRD ISLAND I) WAS CONSTRUCTED IN 2005, AND CONSISTS OF A 5-ACRE, HORSESHOE-SHAPED CLAY ISLAND PROTECTED WITH RIP-RAP WITH MARSH MOUNDS IN THE INTERIOR PLUS A 2-ACRE OYSTER REEF ADJACENT TO THE ISLAND. IN 2011, THE COASTAL PROGRAM IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE GALVESTON BAY FOUNDATION, RESTORE AMERICA'S ESTUARIES - NATIONAL OCEANOGRAPHIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION, AND GALVESTON BAY ESTUARY PROGRAM - TEXAS COMMISSION ON ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY, FUNDED THE BATHYMETRIC STUDIES, THE DESIGN AND ENGINEERING PROPOSAL AND U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS PERMITS NEEDED TO CONSTRUCT DICKINSON BAY ISLAND II. CONSTRUCTION OF DICKINSON BAY ISLAND II WAS FUNDED THROUGH DEEPWATER HORIZON NATURAL RESOURCE DAMAGE ASSESSMENT FUNDS. THE GALVESTON BAY FOUNDATION PROPOSES TO CARRY OUT SEVERAL TASKS IN SUPPORT OF THE PROJECT TO ESTABLISH VEGETATION AND TO ASSESS THE BIOLOGICAL OUTCOME OF THE PROJECT. THESE TASKS INCORPORATE STRATEGIC HABITAT CONSERVATION, I.E. MONITORING PROJECT PERFORMANCE, AND ALSO INCLUDES IMPLEMENTING VEGETATION RESTORATION ACTIONS. A VEGETATION PLAN WILL BE DEVELOPED COOPERATIVELY WITH U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE TO CREATE NESTING HABITAT FOR DIFFERENT GUILDS. GIVEN THE LENGTH OF TIME REQUIRED FOR BIRD NESTING ISLANDS TO MATURE, THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE A 5-YEAR MONITORING PLAN TO DOCUMENT ISLAND STABILITY BIRD USE AND VEGETATION COVER. THE RESULTS OF THIS MONITORING EFFORT WILL INFORM BIRD NESTING ISLAND DESIGN AND RESTORATION ACTIONS FOR OTHER PARTS OF THE TEXAS COAST.

GOALS: THE LONG-TERM GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO RESTORE AND ENHANCE THE GLOBALLY SIGNIFICANT ECOSYSTEM ATPETOBEGO STATE GAME AREA (PSGA) TO SUPPORT POPULATIONS OF HERPETOFAUNA, RARE AND THREATENED PLANTS,AND WILDLIFE GAME SPECIES. INVESTMENT IN THE PROJECT WILL CONTINUE THE CONTROL OF INVASIVE GLOSSYBUCKTHORN INITIATED UNDER COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT #F18AC00777, REDUCING POPULATIONS TO LEVELSMANAGEABLE BY THE MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (MDNR). A COMPREHENSIVE BOTANICALSURVEY HAS NEVER BEEN CONDUCTED AT PSGA, LIMITING THE INFORMATION AVAILABLE TO MDNR FOR MANAGING THEPROPERTY. PROJECT PARTNERS WILL EXPAND SURVEY AND INVENTORY EFFORTS TO PROVIDE LAND MANAGERS WITH DATAVITAL TO MAINTAINING HEALTHY ECOSYSTEMS AND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS.PSGA AND THE ADJACENT MAPLE BAY NATURAL AREA (MBNA) CREATE ROUGHLY 4.8 MILES OF CONTIGUOUS SHORELINEALONG THE EAST ARM OF GRAND TRAVERSE BAY. BOTH THE FEDERALLY THREATENED PITCHER'S THISTLE (CIRSIUMPITCHERI) AND STATE THREATENED LAKE HURON TANSY (TANACETUM HURONENSE) ARE KNOWN TO OCCUR AT THESESITES. CONTINUED CONTROL OF INVASIVE GLOSSY BUCKTHORN ALONG THE WOODLAND EDGE WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT THESESPECIES BY PROTECTING THE BEACH AND DUNES WHERE THEY ARE LOCATED.REMOVAL OF INVASIVE SPECIES FROM PSGA WILL NOT ONLY HELP PROTECT THE RARE AND THREATENED SPECIESPRESENT THERE, BUT WILL ALSO DIRECTLY BENEFIT PRIORITY GAME SPECIES IDENTIFIED IN THE PSGA MASTER PLANINCLUDING WHITE-TAILED DEER, WOOD DUCK, RUFFED GROUSE, COTTONTAIL, AND MALLARDS.ACTIVITIES: FUNDING OF THIS PROPOSAL WILL ALLOW THE GRAND TRAVERSE REGIONAL LAND CONSERVANCY (GTRLC) TOHIRE AN INVASIVE SPECIES CONTRACTOR TO CONDUCT TREATMENT OF INVASIVE GLOSSY BUCKTHORN ACROSS 130 ACRESOF THE MOST HEAVILY IMPACTED AREAS AT PSGA. GTRLC WILL SUPPORT THESE EFFORTS BY SURVEYING AND TREATINGTHE SURROUNDING AREA, APPROXIMATELY 129 ACRES, TARGETING SATELLITE POPULATIONS TO FURTHER LIMIT THESPREAD OF BUCKTHORN THROUGHOUT THE PROPERTY.BUILDING ON THE SUCCESS OF VOLUNTEER WORKDAYS AT THE ADJACENT MBNA, GTRLC WILL HOST 4 WORKDAYSTARGETING INVASIVE SPECIES ON 5 ACRES OF RELATIVELY PRISTINE COASTAL DUNE HABITAT FOUND AT PSGA. TARGETSPECIES WILL BE EXPANDED TO INCLUDE SPOTTED KNAPWEED AND BLADDER CAMPION WHICH DIRECTLY COMPETEWITH LAKE HURON TANSY AND PITCHER'S THISTLE AT THE SITE.FINALLY, GTRLC WILL CONDUCT BOTANICAL SURVEYS OF HIGH PRIORITY HABITAT AT PSGA, DEVELOP A SPECIES LIST FORTHE PROPERTY, AND UPDATE NATURAL COMMUNITY DATA PROVIDING GREATER RESOLUTION FOR DETERMININGAPPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS.OUTCOMES: DATA COLLECTED THROUGHOUT THE LIFE OF THIS PROJECT, AND UNDER COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT#F18AC00777, WILL BE ANALYZED AND PRESENTED AS AN INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT PLAN TO MDNR. THISPLAN WILL OUTLINE EFFORTS TAKEN TO CONTROL GLOSSY BUCKTHORN ACROSS 259 ACRES AT THE SITE, PROVIDE INVASIVESPECIES DISTRIBUTION AND POPULATION DATA, IDENTIFY KEY STANDS REQUIRING REPEATED TREATMENT, AND OUTLINEACTIONS NECESSARY TO MAINTAIN HABITAT INTEGRITY BEYOND THE LIFE OF THE PROJECT.CONTINUED RESTORATION OF PETOBEGO STATE GAME AREA TO MEET THE HABITAT REQUIREMENTS OF HERPETOFAUNAAND THREATENED PLANTS WILL RESULT IN HEALTHY, FUNCTIONAL ECOSYSTEMS THAT ARE CAPABLE OF SUPPORTING ARANGE OF WILDLIFE AND THE NATURAL RESOURCES THAT LOCAL COMMUNITY MEMBERS DEPEND ON. FURTHERMORE, THEPROJECT AREA REPRESENTS THE NORTHERN EXTENT FOR SOME OF THESE SPECIES IN MICHIGAN AND RESTORATION WILLPARTICULARLY BENEFIT THOSE AT-RISK POPULATIONS. INFORMATION AND FINDINGS COMPILED AS A RESULT OF THIS WORKWILL BE PROVIDED AS HABITAT MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS TO BE INCORPORATED INTO MASTER PLANS BYMDNR.THE PROJECT WILL ALSO MAINTAIN AND BUILD UPON CURRENT COLLABORATION AND COOPERATION BETWEEN USFWS,MDNR, AND GTRLC, DEMONSTRATING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF PROJECTS ENGAGING STAKEHOLDERS AT THE FEDERAL,STATE, AND LOCAL LEVEL.

GOALS: THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PLAN AND HOST THE 2022 GREAT LAKES COASTAL SYMPOSIUM IN SAULT STE. MARIE, MI, WHICH WILL ALLOW FOR NATURAL RESOURCES PRACTITIONERS, RESEARCHERS, MANAGERS, STAKEHOLDERS, AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN THE GREAT LAKES TO SHARE RESEARCH, LEARN FROM ONE ANOTHER, AND NETWORK IN SUPPORT OF COASTAL SYSTEMS CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION IN THE GREAT LAKES.THIS IS A SHORT-TERM PROJECT AND IS EXPECTED TO BE COMPLETE PRIOR TO YEAR-END 2022. OBJECTIVES INCLUDE:1. HIRING AN EVENT PLANNER FOR ASSISTANCE PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTING THE 2022 GREAT LAKES COASTAL SYMPOSIUM.2. CONTRACTING WITH AN EXPERIENCED ORGANIZATION TO IMPROVE COASTAL SYMPOSIUM PLANNING, COMMUNICATIONS, AND FUNDRAISING OUTCOMES.3. INCREASING INTERNAL CAPACITY TO CONTRIBUTE TO COASTAL SYMPOSIUM PLANNING BY HIRING A PART-TIME COORDINATOR THAT WILL PROVIDE ON-THE-GROUND ASSISTANCE WITH EVENT PLANNING AND LOGISTICS.4. DEVELOPING A WEBSITE THAT CAN BE USED TO SUPPORT REGISTRATION AND SHARE EVENT INFORMATION FOR THE GREAT LAKES COASTAL SYMPOSIUM, AND MORE GENERALLY BY THE GREAT LAKES COASTAL ASSEMBLY.5. HOSTING THE 2022 GREAT LAKES COASTAL SYMPOSIUM, WITH ATTENDANCE BY MORE THAN 100 PEOPLE.OUTCOMES AND CONTRIBUTIONS: THIS PROJECT, AND MOREOVER THE GREAT LAKES COASTAL SYMPOSIUM, WILL SUPPORT THE GREAT LAKES COASTAL PROGRAM'S STRATEGIC GOALS II (BROADENING AND STRENGTHENING PARTNERSHIPS) AND III (IMPROVING INFORMATION SHARING AND COMMUNICATION). THE OPPORTUNITY FOR STAKEHOLDERS TO GATHER AT THE COASTAL SYMPOSIUM TO NETWORK, SHARE INFORMATION, AND DISCUSS COLLABORATION OPPORTUNITIES WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE OBJECTIVE OF CULTIVATING NEW PARTNERSHIPS AND MAINTAINING EXISTING PARTNERSHIPS. ADDITIONALLY, OPPORTUNITIES AT THE COASTAL SYMPOSIUM WILL CONTRIBUTE DIRECTLY TO IMPROVING COMMUNICATION AND COORDINATION WITHIN THE SERVICE AND WITH EXTERNAL PARTNERS.POPULATIONS TO BE SERVED: GIVEN THE GEOGRAPHIC AND SOCIAL CONTEXT OF SAULT STE. MARIE AS A HOST SITE LOCATION, THERE IS AN OPPORTUNITY TO HOST A TRULY MULTI-NATIONAL COASTAL SYMPOSIUM, AS SAULT STE. MARIE, MICHIGAN AND SAULT STE. MARIE, ONTARIO SHARE AN INTERNATIONAL BORDER ON THE ST. MARYS RIVER, WHICH IS HOME TO A NUMBER OF TRIBES AND FIRST NATIONS (E.G., SAULT TRIBE, BAY MILLS INDIAN COMMUNITY, GARDEN RIVER FIRST NATION, BATCHEWANA FIRST NATION). A MULTI-NATIONAL COASTAL SYMPOSIUM IS A UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY TO GATHER AND LEARN FROM UNIQUE AND DIVERSE COMMUNITIES, INCLUDING INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES THAT HAVE SERVED AS CARETAKERS FOR THE GREAT LAKES FOR MILLENNIA.PRIMARY ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED BY THE RECIPIENT: THE RECIPIENT OF THIS AWARD WILL CONTRIBUTE TO COASTAL SYMPOSIUM EVENT PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION, COORDINATION AMONG OTHER PARTIES, INCLUDING THROUGH HIRING A PART-TIME COORDINATOR TO ASSIST WITH SYMPOSIUM PLANNING, AND WILL CONTRACT WITH TWO ORGANIZATIONS TO CONTRIBUTE TO EVENT PLANNING, EVENT COMMUNICATIONS, AND EVENT SPONSORSHIPS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: RECIPIENTS OF PROJECT CONTRACTS WILL CONTRIBUTE TO EVENT PLANNING AND LOGISTICS, MANAGEMENT OF EVENT FINANCES, DEVELOPMENT OF AN EVENT WEBSITE, AND BY ASSISTING WITH EVENT COMMUNICATIONS AND OBTAINING SPONSORSHIPS.

THE GRANT AGREEMENT WILL UTILIZE THE COMBINED EFFORTS OF THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE), CHESAPEAKE BAY FIELD OFFICE AND THE UNIVERSITY OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA TO SUPPORT ACTIVITIES OF THE URBAN WATERS FEDERAL PARTNERSHIP -ANACOSTIA. THE PARTNERSHIP COMPRISES 15 FEDERAL AGENCIES AND 28 NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS WORKING COLLABORATIVELY IN 20 DESIGNATED LOCATIONS. ITS GOALS ARE TO HELP URBAN AND METROPOLITAN AREAS, PARTICULARLY THOSE THAT ARE UNDERSERVED OR ECONOMICALLY DISTRESSED, WITH THEIR WATERWAYS. THROUGH THIS GRANT, THE UNIVERSITY WILL RECEIVE FUNDS TO PARTIALLY SUPPORT THE AMBASSADOR POSITION WHO WILL PROMOTE AND COORDINATE PROGRAMS AND ACTIVITIES IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES EAST OF THE ANACOSTIA RIVER. THESE ACTIVITIES INCLUDE DEVELOPING ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES AND PUBLIC ADVOCACY CAREER PATHWAYS IN THE ANACOSTIA HIGH SCHOOL FEEDER PATTERN. THE SERVICE WILL WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE AMBASSADOR TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS TO LEARN AND PARTICIPATE IN FIELD AND LABORATORY WORK THAT WILL HELP THEM UNDERSTAND THE SCIENTIFIC ISSUES INVOLVED IN CLEANING THE ANACOSTIA WATERSHED. THE AMBASSADOR WILL CONVENE A MEETING OF THE URBAN WATERS PARTNERS AND DEVELOP ON-THE-GROUND COMMUNITY-BASED PROJECTS THAT WILL EDUCATE CITIZENS OF ALL AGES ON THE RESOURCES, ISSUES, AND OPPORTUNITIES ALONG THE SHORELINE, TRIBUTARIES, AND MAINSTEM RIVER. IN THE PAST, PARTNERSHIP ACTIVITIES INCLUDED THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE EAST CAPITOL URBAN FARM, A 3-ACRE AGRICULTURAL EDUCATION CENTER. IT IS LIKELY THAT ADDITIONAL WORK ON THE FARM WILL BE PART OF THE 2022 PROGRAMMING. THE DELIVERABLES AND OUTCOMES WILL INCLUDE DEVELOPING A WORK PLAN FOR THE COMMUNITY-BASED PROJECTS, ENGAGING CITIZENS IN THESE ACTIVITIES, AND COMMUNICATING THE RESULTS IN VARIOUS FORMS OF MEDIA. THE AMBASSADOR WILL PREPARE AN ANNUAL REPORT. THE BENEFICIARIES OF THE GRANT WILL BE THE CITIZENS OF WASHINGTON, DC AND ESPECIALLY YOUTH AT ANACOSTIA HIGH SCHOOL AND OTHER SCHOOLS.

WESTERN LILY (LILIUM OCCIDENTALE, ABBREVIATED AS LIOC) IS A FEDERAL AND STATE (OREGON[OR] AND CALIFORNIA[CA]) LISTED  ENDANGERED SPECIES. IT HAS A VERY SMALL RANGE ALONG THE PACIFIC COAST STRADDLING THE OR/CA  BORDER. MANY OF THE KNOWN LIOC SITES IN OREGON HAVE DECLINED OR BECOME EXTIRPATED SINCE THE  FIRST SPECIES STATUS REPORT WAS COMPLETED IN 1989. SINCE THAT TIME, MONITORING EFFORTS HAVE BEEN  SPORADIC AND OPPORTUNISTIC. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO GAIN CURRENT DATA ON THE POPULATION  STATUS OF ALL KNOWN LIOC SITES IN OREGON FOR WHICH THE USFWS HAS ACCESS. EACH SITE WILL BE  MAPPED AND CENSUSED WITHIN THE NEXT TWO YEARS DURING THE FLOWERING PERIOD ACCORDING TO A  PROTOCOL THAT THE RECIPIENT WILL DEVELOP IN COLLABORATION WITH THE USFWS. THE PROTOCOL WILL BE  LOGISTICALLY FEASIBLE, GIVEN THE DENSELY VEGETATED CONDITION OF SOME OF THE SITES, AND WILL BE  REPLICABLE IN THE FUTURE. THE END RESULT OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE A FULL POPULATION ASSESSMENT OF  LIOC SITES IN OREGON, ENABLING A MORE ACCURATE UNDERSTANDING OF THIS SPECIES' STATUS AND  INFORMING CONSERVATION ACTIONS NECESSARY TO SUPPORT THE LIOC'S PERSISTENCE IN OREGON.

THE USFWS WILL WORK COLLABORATIVELY WITH TUI TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A COMPREHENSIVE STRATEGY TO SUPPORT THE PRODUCTION AND DISTRIBUTION OF NATIVE PLANT MATERIALS FOR THE PISTOL RIVER PROJECT. THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW TUI TO INCREASE ITS CAPACITY TO IDENTIFY MORE SEED SOURCES AND PRODUCE MORE NATIVE PLANTS, RECRUIT ADDITIONAL WILLING LANDOWNERS AND PRODUCERS, AND PROVIDE GENETICALLY APPROPRIATE PLANT MATERIALS TO RESTORE VULNERABLE HABITATS AT PISTOL RIVER STATE PARK.

FRESHWATER MUSSELS IN THE WESTERN UNITED STATES HAVE BEEN IN A STEADY DECLINE OVER THE LAST CENTURY. THE XERCES SOCIETY HAS SPECIFICALLY SEEN A DRAMATIC DECLINE OF WESTERN RIDGED MUSSELS WITHIN OREGON, THEREFORE, THEY HAVE SUBMITTED A PETITION TO ADD WESTERN RIDGED MUSSELS TO THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT, PROVIDING PROTECTION FOR THIS IMPERILED SPECIES. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE XERCES SOCIETY THE COQUILLE WATERSHED ASSOCIATION PROPOSES A SERIES OF FRESHWATER MUSSEL SURVEYS IN THE COQUILLE BASIN DURING THE 2022 FIELD SEASON. A MINIMUM OF 12 SURVEYS WILL BE COMPLETED AND INCLUDE BOTH PRESENCE-ABSENCE SURVEYS AS WELL AS DENSITY SURVEYS. THESE SURVEYS WILL BE INCLUDED IN THE WIDESPREAD OREGON INVENTORY SPEARHEADED BY THE XERCES SOCIETY TO IMPROVE THE CURRENT KNOWLEDGE ON THE WESTERN RIDGE MUSSEL RANGE AND HEALTH OF THE SPECIES.

THIS PROJECT WILL RESTORE COASTAL DUNE SCRUB AND COASTAL DUNE WETLAND HABITAT IN GUADALUPE NIPOMO DUNES NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (GNDNWR). THIS PROJECT WILL REMOVE AND STOP THE SPREAD OF INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES IN TWO PONDS ON GNDNWR, MYRTLE POND AND 3-POND WEST, AND ON THEIR SURROUNDING UPLANDS. MANY OF THE WETLAND FEATURES WITHIN GNDNWR HAVE NO PONDING WATER DUE TO INVASIVE AND OVERGROWN AQUATIC VEGETATION THAT UTILIZE SUBSTANTIAL AMOUNTS OF AVAILABLE WATER. THE DUNES IMMEDIATELY SURROUNDING MYRTLE POND MARK THE SOUTHERN EXTENT OF THE EUROPEAN BEACH GRASS INVASION IN THE DUNES COMPLEX. IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PROJECT WILL PREVENT ENCROACHMENT OF THE SPECIES SOUTH INTO SANTA BARBARA COUNTY. MYRTLE POND WAS THE ONLY POND WHERE CALIFORNIA RED-LEGGED FROG WAS CONSISTENTLY OBSERVED ON THE REFUGE DURING THE DROUGHT DUE TO ITS PERSISTENT HYDROLOGY. ONLY FIVE OCCURRENCES OF LA GRACIOSA THISTLE REMAIN THROUGHOUT ITS RANGE, WITH ONE BEING AT 3-POND WEST. LA GRACIOSA THISTLE SEEDS WILL BE COLLECTED, GROWN, AND OUTPLANTED ON GNDNWR. AFTER RESTORATION ACTIVITIES ARE COMPLETED, LA GRACIOSA THISTLE WILL BE OUTPLANTED AT MYRTLE POND TO ESTABLISH AN ADDITIONAL VIABLE OCCURRENCE OF THE SPECIES AND THE POPULATION AT 3-POND WEST WILL BE AUGMENTED WITH LA GRACIOSA THISTLE OUTPLANTINGS.

THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE COHO SALMON REARING AND REFUGIA HABITATS WITHIN THE ROGUE RIVER ESTUARY. LACK OF INSTREAM COMPLEXITY AND FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY IS HIGHLIGHTED AS A KEY STRESSOR FOR ALL COHO POPULATIONS IN THE ROGUE. THIS LIMITING FACTOR ALSO IMPACTS SUITABLE HABITAT FOR STEELHEAD, CHINOOK, AMPHIBIANS, REPTILES, AND BEAVER IN THE BASIN. THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO INCREASE SUITABLE YEAR ROUND HABITAT FOR ALL FRESHWATER LIFE STAGES OF COHO AND OTHER NATIVE SALMONIDS, WHILE ALSO SUPPORTING CHANNEL/FLOODPLAIN PROCESSES THAT WILL BENEFIT OTHER NATIVE AQUATIC SPECIES. THE ACTIONS PROPOSED TO REDUCE THE LIMITING FACTOR OF STRUCTURAL COMPLEXITY AND CONNECTIVITY IS TO ADD LARGE WOOD TO FLOODPLAINS AND SLOUGHS TO PROVIDE HABITAT COMPLEXITY, AND TO REVEGETATE RIPARIAN AREAS WITH NATIVE SPECIES TO PROVIDE A LONG TERM SOURCE OF WOOD, FLOODPLAIN ROUGHNESS, AND DIVERSITY AS WELL AS OVERHANGING COVER TO SLOW THE RATE OF WATER WARMING AND SUPPORT INSECT PRODUCTION FOR FISH. THIS LOCATION HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED AS A HIGH PRIORITY AREA IN THE SOUTHERN OREGON NORTHERN CALIFORNIA COHO RECOVERY PLAN. THIS PROJECT WILL HELP CATALYZE GREATER AND MORE EXTENSIVE INVESTMENT IN THIS PRIORITY AREA, LEADING TO ADDITIONAL RESTORATION BENEFITS OVER TIME.

THE USFWS WILL WORK COLLABORATIVELY WITH THE PROJECT PROPONENT TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A COMPREHENSIVE STRATEGY TO ENHANCE WESTERN MONARCH AND OTHER POLLINATOR SPECIES HABITAT IN SOUTHWEST OREGON.  SPECIFICALLY, THE STRATEGY WILL DRAW UPON THE STRENGTHS OF TWO GRASSROOTS CONSERVATION INITIATIVES, THE SOUTHWEST OREGON POLLINATOR COLLABORATIVE (SWOPC) AND THE ROGUE NATIVE PLANT PARTNERSHIP (RNPP) TO ACHIEVE GOALS SET FORTH IN THE WESTERN ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES WESTERN MONARCH CONSERVATION PLAN AS WELL AS THE XERCES SOCIETY'S CALL TO ACTION FOR THE WESTERN POPULATION.  THERE IS A HEIGHTENED SENSE OF URGENCY TO ADDRESS A SIGNIFICANT DECLINE IN THE WESTERN POPULATION OF 99.4% SINCE THE 1980S. SWOPC RECENTLY COMPLETED OVER 300 ACRES OF NATIVE PLANT RESTORATION THAT ENHANCED OR CREATED MONARCH HABITAT IN THE PROJECT AREA, AND THE RNPP IS COLLECTING AND GROWING OUT NATIVE SEED TO PROVIDE THE NEEDED PLANT MATERIALS. THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW THESE ENTITIES TO INCREASE THEIR CAPACITY TO IDENTIFY MORE SEED SOURCES AND PRODUCE MORE NATIVE PLANTS, RECRUIT ADDITIONAL WILLING LANDOWNERS, AND PROVIDE THEM WITH TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND PLANT MATERIALS.

THE OREGON SILVERSPOT (OSB) IS A FEDERALLY THREATENED BUTTERFLY THAT OCCUPIES COASTAL PRAIRIE SUPPORTING ITS LARVAL HOST PLANT, THE EARLY BLUE VIOLET.  HABITAT LOSS HAS REDUCED THE SPECIES TO FIVE POPULATIONS.  THE SECOND LARGEST POPULATION, LOCATED AT BIG CREEK, IS ESTIMATED TO CONTAIN ONLY 45 BUTTERFLIES.  CONSEQUENTLY, BIG CREEK IS CONSIDERED A PRIORITY AREA FOR RECOVERY EFFORTS BY THE USFWS AND THE OREGON PARKS AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT (OPRD) WHICH OWNS THE SITE.  THE AREA ALSO CONTAINS 132 ACRES OF FEDERALLY DESIGNATED CRITICAL HABITAT THAT OVERLAPS WITH ADJACENT USFS LANDS.  INVASIVE SPECIES ARE PROLIFIC, AND THE AREA IS BADLY IN NEED OF RESTORATION WITH NATIVE NECTAR PLANTS AND VIOLETS.  THEREFORE THIS PROJECT WILL GROW 9000 PLANTS IN THE OPRD NATIVE PLANT NURSERY WHILE CONTRACTING OUT THE GROWING OF 25,000 MORE PLANTS.  THESE PLANTS WILL BE PLANTED ON OPRD AND USFS LANDS FOLLOWING SITE PREPARATION TO REMOVE WEEDY SPECIES.  FUNDS FROM THE COASTAL PROGRAM WILL BE USED GROW AND INSTALL PLANTS, ALLOWING FOR THE ENHANCEMENT OF 5 ACRES OF COASTAL PRAIRIE.  FUTURE PLANS INCLUDE AUGMENTING THE POPULATION OF OSB WITH CAPTIVE REARED CATERPILLARS.

PRIORITIES WITHIN THESE FOCUS AREAS.
